column1: I overall love this game but ive taken my thumbs up away until you either nerf the power fist weapon in pvp or the bulwark class. The stats for powerfist look bad but yet im watching people 1 shot any class with it even heavy and bulwark classes. So youve put a talentless weapon on a low skill class. Either the power fist needs heavy nerfs to oblivion or you need to nerf bulwark so that its shield can only take so many hits before needing to recharge similar to heavy class in pvp. Theres no reason a class is having god mode in a frontal cone and then just 1 shotting people on repeat. Fix this and you earn your thumbs up back."

column5:
Posted: November 12
Its honestly not a terrible game. The campaign is decent enough, and i did like the characters a good bit. But the gameplay, especially in Operations is rather shallow. It doesn't sell that power fantasy of being a Primaris Ultramarine. Many weapons do not feel good to use and the build diversity is rather shallow. The depth of mechanics is also quite shallow as well, Exemplified by a single key press letting you basically take your hands off the keyboard for a second or two because of a drawn out (albeit badass) execution animation. Lacks good horde numbers too. There just isnt enough enemies to sell me on the fact im facing a world ending threat.

Is it a bad game? Absolutely not. if you do buy this there is a good chance you'll enjoy it. But at 60 usd i cannot personally say its worth the money until they add.. More. More Builds, More Depth, More Missions.
Its a mid game that costs too much in my opinion.

Posted: September 10
Very tough decision for me to give this a not recommended review, but I think there are some glaring issues that should be addressed.

First off, the pros:
1. It looks great. Starting from the bigger things. The game is set on three very different and distinct planets: Kadaku, a jungle world, Avarax, a hive world and Demerium, a cemetery world. Each of the planets have their very own distinct style and feel to it. Then down to the smaller details. There are a lot of details in the game that also breath life into the game and adds to the whole WH40K experience. Bravo.
2. The gameplay is great. If you enjoyed the first space marine game, odds are, you will enjoy this one as well. The melee and shooting all feel very satisfying. Popping off a headshot or pulling off a finisher all feel very satisfying.
3. The story is pretty good. I mean, Warhammer games are not always known for having interesting stories, especially also considering this game is supposed to be a hack and slash kinda brainless fun game. All in all, I enjoyed the story thus far. Additional points go to the fact that the coop missions are also parallel to the main missions.

Next, onto the cons:
1. The story is a bit short for its price. There are 7 main story missions (8 if you count prologue) and 5 coop missions that will help flesh out the main story missions (6 if you count Ballistic engine, which isn't really mentioned anywhere in the main missions). I did the game on Angels of Death difficulty and it should take about 15 hours to complete. If you count the coop missions in, it should take about 25-30 hours in total if you wanna enjoy the whole story at least once. Slightly on the short side for the price they are charging.
2. It can be a real grindfest. Tying into the last point. What it does not have in length, it makes up for the sheer amount of grind you will need to do. To unlock all the armor sets for each class, you need to play 35 matches per class, with a total of 210 matches. Assuming you don't do PvP like I do, let's assume each match takes 30 minutes (I think that's the bare minimum unless you do speedrun), and you win every single match. That is like 100+ hours right there that requires you to grind. Now, I'm not against having a lot of coop time to pad out the game time, but since there are only six maps, things can get stale real soon. I hate doing comparisons, but If you compare it with games like Vermintide 2. Vermintide 2 had 13 missions in total when it first launched, which will ensure a relatively healthy mix of varied missions. Here's hoping the devs would add in more coop missions down the line.
3. Twitch drops. Really? I mean, all the clown awards that went into the announcement post should be telling. It is one thing to do exclusive twitch drops that requires you to watch it (since you can just leave it in the background), it is altogether another to require people subbing and giving out subscriptions. This is toxic.

All in all, I enjoyed the game itself, but I really do not enjoy some of the other decisions the devs made for the game.

Posted: October 19
I'm amending my initial review in the wake of the 4.1 patch. Snippets of the original review will be referenced below for the sake of continuity (not all of it, because character limits), but reading the original won't have been necessary.

Bottom line up front: if you're a fan of 40k, really like co-op PvE games, and don't mind dropping 60 bones on a game that's light on content right now, you can probably go ahead and snag this without being too disappointed. If you aren't described by all three of those points -- definitely wait for a sale. Honestly, you're probably better off waiting for a sale even if you're fine with all that.

Changing my review to a recommendation, with some caveats. The core of what's here is solid, but there are enough negatives that I have to add some points of caution to that.

Starting with the positives: the game good. Some of the guns are still somewhat lackluster in spite of recent tweaks intended to buff their viability in later difficulties, but it's still possible to get through the highest difficulties with anything on the table. Gunplay isn't the highlight here though -- melee is where SM2 shines. If you run parry-centric builds in souls-likes, you'll be right at home here. While there are non-parry focused melee weapon options available, one of the chief mechanics players rely on is recovering armor (think of it as a regenerating shield) through executions. It is also possible to recover armor by parrying small enemies that attack you ("minoris" enemies, as the game terms them) -- so being able to parry efficiently is one of the main ways to stay alive in this game. It's a blast in co-op, and frankly that's where I've spent all but two or so hours of time in this game.

I'm not the biggest 40k fan, but from everything I've seen they've been true to the lore of the 40k universe. This is likely because GW is intensely protective of their IP, and had granular input on seemingly pointless details like the specific look of ankle armor for the Space Marines. If lore accuracy is important to you, you'll appreciate this game.

All that said...there are some issues that are still in play.

Out the gate, the content for the game is fairly thin. The Campaign mode can be completed in roughly 6-8 hours if you're taking your time or still learning mechanics, and the Operations mode (where I suspect most players spend most of their time -- at least, that's the case for me) has 7 different missions right now. Each of those missions can be finished in 30-45 minutes, depending on how thoroughly you scour the environment for items. There's a PvP mode, but it's seemingly an afterthought that was just bolted on, because there's only three maps available there, and balancing there is .

In fact, the dev team for Space Marine 2 with the concept of balance in both PvP and PvE. Part of the furor over the 4.0 patch was due to changes that nerfed the existing meta strategies, without providing alternatives, effectively destroying the power fantasy aspect of their power fantasy game. Recent changes have moved the needle more towards this being an actual balancing effort, but there's still work to do.

Example: in my initial review, I had complaints about nerfs applied to the melta bomb -- a single charge grenade type deployable that was being used to deal massive amounts of damage to Terminus (mini-boss) and larger enemies. The approach taken by the devs was to reduce the damage these items do to those enemies by 70%. Thus, a melta bomb does just about nothing to a mini-boss, but a krak grenade will still take away chunks of its health -- and you get two krak grenades per pick up.

As I stated previously -- there's already a mechanic that limits the amount of damage a melta bomb can do, and it's called "item rarity." You start a round with three frag grenades. If you get a melta bomb, it's because the RNG saw fit to give you one. A melta bomb is supposed to be a big, nuclear option tool used to deal with big hordes or big enemies. If it can't do that job, what incentive do we have to take it?

Another issue is that this dev team has a habit of making changes to the game without documenting them. The problem here is that if the community has no idea what changes have been made to core elements of gameplay, it's going to be impossible for players to provide meaningful feedback on those changes, leaving us to just guess or go off vibes that something "feels different." If you're shooting from the hip and making changes to your game without telling people what's getting tweaked, you're setting yourself up for public outcry, and you deserve every ounce of grief you get in response.

fact, the dev team is fairly bad at communicating with users n general. Prior to the 4.0 patch, the community was told that the upcoming changes would include a new map, additional cosmetics and a new weapon. The map dropped, but the other items are still MIA, and so far as I've seen, the devs have not provided any information clarifying a different release date for these items, or an explanation for their absence.

Finally, there are still a handful of "little" problems that take away from the whole experience. I still occasionally see a bug where weapon XP is not properly allocated to the weapon used during a mission, meaning no progress is made towards unlocking the next quality tier for that weapon despite a successful run. Various classes and weapons still have useless (or borderline useless) perks, some of which can outright kill a player. The netcode has improved, but random disconnects are still a thing. Players on both AMD and nVidia cards have reported crashes at various times in the game's life cycle: at launch, AMD cards were having issues, but recently it seems to be nVidia users getting the short end of the stick. There's also the issue where if you're joined with a group via matchmaking and your preferred class is already being used, you're forced to pick another class (without an accompanying opportunity to make sure you've got an appropriate weapon load out for the map you're playing).

I'm having a good time with this game, obviously -- the number of hours I've played is plainly visible here. But I can only recommend this game with caveats. If you love 40k, like co-op PvE games, and don't mind dropping 60 bones on a game that's light on content, grab it. You'll have fun, and you can certainly squeeze plenty of hours out of repeating the Operations missions. I have.

If all three of those descriptors don't fit you though...wait for a sale. Just wait. I can easily see people getting a case of buyer's remorse buying this at 60. In all honesty, I'd recommend you wait even if those DO describe you. There's a good game here, but I can't say it's completely worth the price of admission right now. I don't exactly have buyer's remorse myself, but neither am I glad I spent that money.

Posted: September 7
I have been wanting to play a sequel to Space Marine since the first game launched in 2011. To finally be able to play the sequel to it was fantastic! I love everything about Space Marines and the game in general so I bought the Ultra Edition of the game instantly so nothing would be spoiled for me via the internet.

Was the wait for Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 worth it? Is it a good game? Is it a worthy successor to Space Marine (1)? Yes. Yes it was and I am glad I paid to play early because I loved and still am, currently loving everything about the game. Below I will explain why I am loving Space Marine 2 but first, a quick disclaimer!

This review is MY opinion, MY own personal experience and MY thoughts. I am brutally honest when it comes to reviewing games. If you do not like my opinion, my time or respect my personal experience, please move on.

âš«In terms of optimisation - the game has no lag, stutter, fps drops, freezing e.t.c. Space Marine 2 is technically not out yet as of writing this review (paid to play early) and the game runs smoother than butter. Is this because Denuvo DRM is not on the game? Probably.
âš«The visuals/Graphic are beyond AMAZING and even on low specs, they look stunning.
âš«Fighting off the THOUSANDS of Tyranids that are coming to turn you into a bloody gore pit on the floor was PHENOMENAL. Watching them make the "pyramid" to climb up the walls and you punch, shoot, crush, stomp - OBLITERATE them from the face of the planet... the gore, the blood, the animations... all of which are so spot on.
âš«The game has a LORE-ACCURATE art direction which ANY 40k fan will respect and to top that off the lore is accurate and faithful to true canon lore. Compared to some "recent" 40k games - Space Marine 2 is the BEST Warhammer game to be released in over a decade.
âš«The combat system is stellar. Ranging from melee weapons to ranged weapons that work so fluently together in the heat of battle. Doing the melee combos to stun and then being able to point your gun - executioner style to kill them... felt so good.
âš«Enemy variety will keep you on your toes almost at all times. Not only are they "unique" they all have their own behaviours and abilities which will put your skills to the test of a true Space Marine.
âš«On harder difficulties the enemies seem to dynamically change their movesets (either this is true or I suck on veteran+) and, I am not kidding here, will TRULY test your skills. Harder difficulty campaign (or ops) will be a true test of player skill as you need to perfect your dodging and parrying ability because in the end - this show the true lethality of mankind's enemies in the 40k universe.
âš«The story was very well written and I enjoyed it from start to finish. It had interesting moments, moments where you would be like "oh no" or "FOR THE OMNISIAH!!!". Not only that, the characters were very well embedded in the story which only enhanced the story even more.
âš«Once you are finished with campaign missions you can play the OPERATIONS MODE (PVE) which run parallel to the base games campaign which has you playing as a different ultramarine squad that lets you level up weapons and several class's. Not only is this mode FANTASTIC, the progression feels rewarding as the longer you go, the harder it gets and more XP you will earn, ontop of that you will earn UNIQUE cosmetics that other players may or may not be able to obtain (as I said, skill based combat).
âš«If PVE mode is not your thing, don't fret! You also gain access to ENDLESS WAR (PVP) which pits Space Marines against the Chaos forces. It brings back the classic game modes such as Deathmatch which I am sure we all know how fun that was in Space Marine! Not only that, if you are struggling to get perks and weapons unlocked in PVP you can just go play PVE for a bit as PVP shares PVE's loadout customisation options.
âš«It has tonnes of content still yet to be released - look at the roadmap. Horde mode.... come on, who doesn't just want to sit and kill thousands, if not millions, of Tyranids for the Emperors name!

âš«The main issue that people are mentioning is the "servers" struggling at the moment - I have noticed this issue only seems to happen if you are playing COOP campaign or ONLINE modes - You can spend about 5-10 minutes on the "loading" screen to only realise that the game is not loading at all and this forces you to restart your game. If you are in Campaign, you will most likely loose all mission progress if you are the COOP partner or miss an important cutscene. This means you might have to replay the mission you had just played.
âš«You cannot order your AI team to do anything. Open a door. Press a button. Heal you. They are a bit "stupid" to say the least. Hey, no games perfect.
âš«There are no collectables or "secrets" to be found. Only Dataslates. I am mentioning this in cons because I feel like they missed a golden opportunity to add little secrets about "past" events or "past" games that have released.
âš«About the point above - there is no point in really exploring as there is nothing to see or find. Just the dataslates and even at that they are not really hidden at all. The maps were very linear full of dead-ends, wished there was a little more "exploring" to be had.

In the end, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is probably the best Warhammer game in a decade. Not only is it faithful to it's lore, it had practically no stutter, lag, fps drops at all, the animations are spot on, the characters are spot on, the world building and story writing were superb... this is what Warhammer should be like when you make it a game!!!

I wholeheartedly, after waiting almost 14/15 years for a new Space Marine game to come out... say this game should be played by everyone, new or old to the 40K universe.

Como fan de Warhammer 40K no puedo estar mas contento de verdad. Es un juego increÃ­ble y parece literalmente que estas viviendo una pelicula.

Cosas buenas:


- Los graficos son de 10, me repito, parece una pelicula.

- Fidelidad absoluta a la franquicia

- Jugabilidad y mecanicas


Malas:

- Hay perdida de frames y un uso de CPU elevado que se va a corregir en parches, asi que no es un problema.

- Los colores del pintaejercitos debarian ser gratuitos. No puedo crear a mi capitulo porque el azul que necesito es de DLC. Creo que lo unico de pago debaria ser cosmetico a nivel armadura sin restringir los colores.

- Algunos colores no quedan bien pintados segun que zonas porque el tono no coincide con el color.

- Rangos DLC. Para crear a los tenientes y a los sargentos veteranos necesitas tambien el patron de DLC y no parece justo tampoco. (Me comprare el DLC mas adelante de todas formas)



Cosas que yo meterÃ­a en el multijugador:


- Que cuando personalices a tu marine los colores aplicados sean tambien aplicados al resto de toda la flota para que de esa forma si tienes un capitulo propio sientas esa inmersiÃ³n.

- El modo PVP deberÃ­a tener un PVE tambien desde mi punto de vista porque yo y todos mis amigos somos jugadores PVE. (Esto no es necesario pero si habria mas gente casual que simplemente quiere pasar un buen rato con sus amigos)

Por lo general no escribo reseÃ±as pero este juego lo merece porque es de 10/10

Posted: October 18
ğŸŸ§ Space Marine 2 sold 4.5 million copies, instead of addressing simple stuff like server connection issues, launch issues and QoL changes. Game devs wanted to 90% focus on nerfing fun gameplay you enjoy in PvE Operations with friends


ğŸ”¸ Still have enemy damage sponges that deal high health damage in higher difficulties you see in Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed Odyssey, forcing you to level up your class to the max level and play like Sekiro and Wo Long Fallen Dynasty (parry heavy games).

ğŸ”¸ Lethal difficulty forces your Classes to really stick together counter-intuitive to the role of Sniper, Vanguard and Assault (they need positioning and at times far from teammates).

ğŸ”¸ Lethal difficulty last brother standing (if your 2 teammates are down) won't let you have a redemption arc cause you cannot gain armor when both of your teammates are down.


ğŸ”¸ For some reason in higher difficulties like Ruthless and Lethal, PvE Operations Space Marines that come from the Battle Barge with so many supplies then get transported by the Thunderhawk to a planet, cannot even bring 1 Medicae Stimms with them.

ğŸ”¸ You cannot choose a grenade type in the Battle Barge before being deployed in PvE Operations even in higher levels but in PvP you can choose a grenade type (when you level up).

ğŸ”¸ For some reason, very simple stuff like changing Helmet Lens Colors and Bulwark Flag Banner is extremely hard to do for them.


ğŸ”¸ No weapons holstered or sheathed on the hip like the Chainsword you see in early trailers of Space Marine 2. Weapons disappear to thin air while doing executions like what you see in FromSoftware games when you open doors there (play Mandragora demo and see how that game lets you sheathe weapons while climbing).

ğŸ”¸ Wants you to register to the Focus website to voice out concerns and ideas, many nice highly upvoted ideas and concerns there are 95% ignored.

ğŸ”¸ Always changing Armor Colors, now you lose some of those colors and some colors still don't match when applied to a different armor part even if they are the same color.


ğŸ”¸ Parry mechanics change: Fencing parry feels weird now and samish to Balanced. Contested health still disappears so fast, add 1 to 2 secs delay before deterioration. Can't get that health back being staggered, interrupted and busy parrying.

ğŸ”¸ Same weapons just different bad stats like very slow attack speed, I read that Space Marines are supposed to be fast why are they so slow? Enemies move and dodge faster.

ğŸ”¸ So many bad perks that are useless in higher difficulty, makes you choose a select few that are viable. 5% damage increase? 3% heal when you execute an Extremis? Choose a perk between 10% damage for the Tyranids and Chaos?


ğŸ”¸ For some reason you get staggered and interrupted a lot even with the perks "do not lose control while charging an attack" and "after being grabbed, not lose control when taking heavy hits"

ğŸ”¸ Assault Class loses the ability to fly-hover, air-dash, shoot and drop grenades while flying in PvE Operations (play an Assault Class in PvP Eternal War you will know what I am talking about, when you high jump, tap the ability again to air hover).

ğŸ”¸Assault Class eats 1 charge of the Jump Pack when you Dash with it instead of half a charge, Jump Pack is actually used twice during Ground and Pound (once during lift and used again during ground smash) but eats only 1 charge.


ğŸ”¸ Vanguard Class loses the ability to grapple environments in PvE Operations (play a Vanguard in PvP Eternal War and you can grapple to walls, windows and ground).

ğŸ”¸ Very limited pistol choices for the Sniper, Vanguard and Assault Classes.

ğŸ”¸ No shield charge for the Bulwark class, even Fortnite has Captain America's shield charge.


ğŸ”¸ Grindfest MMO and Mobile leveling style for each class, there are 6 classes, you have to replay PvP and PvE countless times

ğŸ”¸ Their idea of padding up gameplay is grinding the same map over and over again. The Tyranid Hierophant Bio-Titan has a smoke screen but the Space Marines do not have a smoke grenade to lose enemy aggro so you can revive a teammate and range enemies to lose accuracy when you are inside the smoke?

ğŸ”¸ Saber Interactive didn't really level up and evolve their talent/perk design coming from their previous game World War Z. Play other games like Dota 2, Hades 1 and 2, Astral Ascent, Ember Knights, etc. to get really good ideas for the Perks system, yours are still the boring, uninnovative, useless in high difficulty perks.




â˜„ï¸ Make Perks actually great that change gameplay in PvE Operations like the Assault Class we enjoy in PvP Eternal War, have him choose among:

ğŸ”¹ Ground Pound Assault Class (what we have now).

ğŸ”¹ Fly-Hover Assault (in PvP Eternal War the Assault Class can fly, hover and dash in the air, shoot his pistol and even throw grenades mid-air). For some ugly reason they won't let you do this in PvE Operations. Air Assault Class.

ğŸ”¹ Jump Pack Dash-Dodge Assault (does not have to be a perfect dodge, jump pack dash eats half a charge and replenishes fast (you can still hover and dash mid-air but don't have damage perks for Ground Pound and Fly Hover). Dash Mobility Evasion Assault Class.


â˜„ï¸ Perks change for the Vanguard Class, let him choose among:

ğŸ”¹ Perks that focus on Grappling Enemies (what we have now). Sekiro and Spiderman web zip Vanguard.

ğŸ”¹ Perks that focus on Grappling Environments (walls and ground) for mobility (fast cooldown) what you see in PvP Eternal Vanguard. Escape and Close-In distance fast Vanguard.

ğŸ”¹ Perks that focus on Parry and Melee combat (you already have some of these perks with the Vanguard Class). Lies of P and Bloodborne Vanguard.

Aos olhos de alguÃ©m que vÃ¡ jogar em dificuldades menores, talvez pareÃ§a bobo, mas se o jogador se empenhar e entender as mecÃ¢nicas para jogar nas dificuldades mais altas, este verÃ¡ que funciona como uma danÃ§a no campo de batalha. HÃ¡ muita complexidade envolvida e nÃ£o se trata apenas de correr e atirar. Sem falar na variedade de armas e seus usos para cada situaÃ§Ã£o especÃ­fica, assim como as diferentes granadas e habilidades tÃ¡ticas.
A gameplay aqui Ã© o FOCO principal, como deve ser em um bom jogo de verdade (pelo menos para mim), e o jogo nÃ£o possui problemas de ritmo e em nenhum momento perde a magia, assim como (citando mais uma vez) Doom 2016 e Doom Eternal, onde ao invÃ©s das coisas ficarem repetitivas pela aÃ§Ã£o extrema, elas ficam ainda melhores pelo aumento da intensidade gradativa, com mais momentos onde a escolha e atitude rÃ¡pida do jogador vÃ£o fazer a diferenÃ§a. O jogo pode ser desafiador em dados momentos, mas se vc entrar no mindset de um space marine e a forÃ§a imparÃ¡vel que vc representa com estratÃ©gia e atitude, vocÃª escaparÃ¡ de qualquer situaÃ§Ã£o, atÃ© mesmo de primeira nas maiores dificuldades, basta se encontrar dentro do jogo, e Ã© isso que Ã© tÃ£o incrÃ­vel dentro da gameplay desse novo Space Marine. No entanto, isso nÃ£o quer dizer que a histÃ³ria nÃ£o seja boa.


Mesmo com a gameplay sendo o foco aqui, nÃ£o quer dizer que a histÃ³ria nÃ£o seja boa, na verdade ela Ã© muito boa, e Ã© contada como os antigos faziam, por meio de boas cutscenes que aparecem do nada e conteÃºdos extra kkkkkkkkk. O universo 40k Ã© rico em MUITA LORE, afinal de contas sÃ£o quase 40 anos de existÃªncia, com milhares de coisas nos wargames e tabuleiro, nos livros dos RPG de mesa, mais de 500 livros e histÃ³rias, animaÃ§Ãµes, quadrinhos, enfim, Ã© coisa para caralho. Mas o jogo ele faz bem em condensar a histÃ³ria para um contexto especÃ­fico e se manter nesse contexto.

SÃ£o como insetos poderosos de rÃ¡pida adaptÃ§Ã£o e evoluÃ§Ã£o que agem sob um poderoso consciente coletivo chamado de Mente Colmeia, ou Hive Mind. Eles sÃ£o inteligentes, miram e atacam em pontos estratÃ©gicos e nÃ£o temem morrer para concluir objetivos essenciais, sÃ£o basicamente uma forÃ§a implacÃ¡vel, sem ambiÃ§Ã£o ou emoÃ§Ãµes para atrapalhar, o Ãºnico objetivo Ã© consumir tudo no universo. E a partir daÃ­ entra em cena nosso protagonista Titus, que retorna depois de ter entrado em contato com um artefato de Caos (outra forÃ§a do universo) e ser marcado pelos inquisidores, sendo enviado para a Deathwatch para lutar contra Xenos em diversos sistemas. No entanto, apÃ³s uma gloriosa e importante vitÃ³ria, Marneus Calgar ordenou o mesmo Ã  voltar para os Ultramarines e lutar novamente por Ultramar! DaÃ­ a histÃ³ria se desenrola com diversos twists envolvendo Astartes traidores corrompidos pelas forÃ§as do Chaos, reviravoltas de personagens interessantes, e claro, muita sanguinolÃªncia e vingaÃ§a. Tenho certeza que a histÃ³ria do jogo irÃ¡ empolgar muitos jogadores e inspirar vÃ¡rios deles a irem atrÃ¡s de conhecer o universo e de repente serem floodados por shorts de lore em todas as redes sociais.


Como vivemos em uma era onde todo mundo estÃ¡ viciado em microdoses de dopamina, e somos todos fodidos da cabeÃ§a buscando alguma espÃ©cie de amparo em qualquer tipinho de conteÃºdo, apenas uma boa campanha nÃ£o basta... Sempre querem mais :rottenwalker: . EntÃ£o Ã©, o jogo tem multiplayer e promessas de conteÃºdo novo Ã  cada season para uma maior longevidade, onde teremos conteÃºdos relacionados a outros CapÃ­tulos de Space Marines, armas novas, inimigos, mapas handcrafted (nada procedural, amÃ©m), e muitas e muitas skins para os fÃ£s fanÃ¡ticos colecionarem. Mas de que se trata esse multiplayuer? Existe o multiplayer da campanha, onde vc pode jogar com mais 2 amigos para completÃ¡-la, e hÃ¡ ainda o modo coop de OperaÃ§Ãµes, onde vocÃª escolhe uma entre as 6 classes disponÃ­veis para completar missÃµes difÃ­ceis no bom e velho estilo de Left 4 Dead 2, com muitas hordas chegando, e objetivos para se completar enquanto isso. HÃ¡ o estÃ­mulo da repetiÃ§Ã£o por meio de lvl ups das armas e das classes, com perks para desbloquear e melhorias de armadura por meio de coletÃ¡veis de nodos de armaduras e sementes genÃ©ticas. AlÃ©m do modo de operaÃ§Ãµes hÃ¡ ainda o pvp, que na minha opiniÃ£o Ã© muito bem vindo e me lembrou bastante a era de ouro dos videogames, lembrando especificamente o multiplayer de Halo. HÃ¡ planos para a vinda de um modo de Horda.



Para fechar essa anÃ¡lise, devo dizer que de fato o jogo Ã© incrÃ­vel, para mim Ã© como um suspiro em uma indÃºstria cada vez pior, com tÃ­tulos onde o que importa de verdade nos jogos Ã© deixado de lado, e onde mecÃ¢nicas simples e o convencionalismo estÃ¡ vencendo para agradar pessoas com "arte em pÃ­lula", pois essas pessoas estÃ£o doentes e cansadas. column5:
Posted: September 10
I'm sure this is a great game, but it's literally unplayable for me right now. My computer is well within the game's required specs, but within less than an hour, I had consistent issues with:

- Texture streaming. Textures sometimes simply wouldn't load, leaving the game a fuzzy mess
- Audio steaming. Music tracks stuttered, audio cut out during dialogue in missions
- Enemy lag. Somehow, in a single-player intro mission, Xenos were teleporting around as if I had connection issues
- Objects disappearing. Ammo crates, med kits just disappeared on interaction for some reason
- No ultrawide support. That's more a personal preference thing, but still

I'm happy for the people able to enjoy this game. Hopefully they address some of the blatant technical issues the game is facing eventually. Will look to try pick this up again in future.

Si bien puede parecer un poco molesto los jefes es cuestiÃ³n de aprender patrones y el como funciona el parri, una vez lo dominas lo terminas derrotando (muchos intentos puede llevar esto, pero no te rindas, satisfacciÃ³n al final del tÃºnel).

Posted: September 15
Loved the first game. This sequel is straight up not enjoyable. The levels are designed around 3 players; if you're playing single player than the AI is absolutely useless. They don't play the objective, they don't prioritize targets, they just run around near you and stab random enemies. If a game is going to force you to use AI teammates, they better be able to pull their own weight.

Multiplayer is somewhat fun, but even that falls short. Game play feels very similar to Halo Infinite, except slower, clunkier, and not as much fun. Also, Halo is free and this is full price.

I played this for four hours before coming to the conclusion that it just isn't fun enough to keep playing. Which is a shame, because if I'd stopped before two hours I could have refunded it.

Posted: September 8
8/10. Combat is extremely fun and engaging, PvP feels way more balanced than I initially expected, the game looks beautiful, and mostly runs great. Feels extremely accurate to the lore, the customization options are insane. The negatives are really just long load times, and while we know we're getting more operations and such, eventually running the same 6 will get a bit stale. However, the higher the difficulty, the more random encounters can happen, and makes the game more exciting, even when doing the same thing over and over. Finished the campaign 2 days ago, been in operations and pvp ever since. Love it here.

Posted: September 17
Space Marine 2 is an excellent sequel to the original, improving on the original game in almost every aspect. As it currently stands, I think it's a great game and represents the 40K universe very well, capturing grand scale combat zones on gorgeous alien planets. That said, it can certainly do with some quality of life improvements, which is to be expected of most new games out the gate. Hopefully they will address certain issues quite quickly, though most of these didn't affect the game in a negative way. More details on that below.

The game itself follows the story from the first game, which was a fairly basic story about the discovery of a relic which brings about nothing but trouble for the protagonist, Titus. Essentially, he is paying penance for his "crime" in the last game, which consists of him not dying. As a result of this, he has grown distrustful of his fellow brothers, which in turn makes his brothers not trust him - along with the obvious fact that he mysteriously vanished for the last couple of centuries. The campaign takes place over 3 planets, while certain storyline events take place concurrently with the Operations game mode, which is essentially another 6 missions in co-op mode, where you can play as a custom Space Marine.

The gameplay is pretty basic. It's very similar to Gears of War without the cover system, instead relying on stunning and executing enemies to restore your overshields. You'll be mixing up melee and gun play mopping up large numbers of basic enemies while eliminating the larger threats, which mostly consist of two large factions each with around 6-7 enemy types each, and some boss type enemies too.

Overall, I do recommend this game, however I do feel that the amount of content itself is a little bit lacking. Saber have made a very good game platform for more content to be added, and I can imagine different scenarios and missions could easily be added to objective mode. Having completed the campaign, it definitely feels as though it's meant to be played co-op too, especially with all the cool cosmetics you can unlock in the multiplayer modes. These additions I feel like would be low effort for the developer, so maybe they will consider it in the future.

Other than the small quality of life improvements and a bit of tweaking on some of the multiplayer classes, I think Saber did an excellent job, and I look forward to more content. The storyline is gripping, the visuals are amazing, and it's the sort of fun gory gameplay that we used to get a lot of in gaming, so it's nice to have a callback to that.


- Excellent visuals that brings the 40K universe to life in an authentic way.
- Captures the essence of the Space Marines in all their glory (though on harder difficulties you won't feel very powerful at all)
- Impressive horde mechanics, particularly in their movement. Climbing up walls and scrambling over each other suits the tyranids amazingly.
- Combat is fairly basic but fun, and glory killing enemies never seems to get old.


- Gaining multiplayer XP is incredibly slow, given that you'll be repeating online content a fair bit. This is exacerbated by the fact that cosmetics use the same currency as productive upgrades such as perk points. I feel like the two should have been separated so you can work towards your favorite chapter AND progress in abilities so you can pull your weight better in teams.
- Melee in particular needs some buffs, as it tends to do little damage compared to firearms.
- Harder difficulties are quite overtuned at the moment. This is especially apparent against ranged enemies, who always seem to have a clear line of sight to your team and make extremely quick work of you while in combat.
- Missing some obvious and easy to implement quality of life improvements, such as a co-op campaign mode, customisable campaign armor sets using cosmetics from the multiplayer, and weapons carrying over from certain chapters. I noticed in the campaign, Titus regularly has his default armor and weapons, which is understandable in CGI cutscenes, but not in the in-game ones. Also, I would have preferred to have the helmets on the team for the custscenes too. There is an option for this, but it only affects gameplay moments.

column5:
Posted: September 14
Introduction

I always wanted to make my own space marine, color it, choose the chapter i want, play with but getting into the 40k Mini's is hard and expensive. But with this game you can immerse yourself in the world of 40k and be a Space Marine for US$60.

Regardless whether you're into 40K or not, if you like 3rd person shooter, fighting xenos (aliens) with 2 other people, that has a good Story Campaign, 6 different classes in Pve Operations mode, and a PVP, then this game is for you

Pros and Cons
(Pros) Immersive and great campaign mode that delves into the 40K universe (especially Ultramarines Chapter which is 40k Warhammer golden boy). (Cons) The campaign is quite short, which is less then 15 hours





So in conclusion, think it's a great game and a lot of fun to play with friends or random. This game had been a blast compared to some of the 40K games released before this, and it lives up to the first Space Marine. Whether or not this game is worth it for those who want to buy it, is up to you. After reading all the pros and cons, reading review, taking it all to consideration, is it worth your time and money? only you can decide :)

Posted: September 11
Der Imperator ist enttÃ¤uscht..

Ich war ein groÃŸer Fan des ersten Space Marine Teil entgegen der negativen Kritiken die es damals hagelte! Insofern war meine Freude das es eine Fortsetzung gibt sehr hoch! Leider kann ich diesem Spiel dennoch keine gute Bewertung dalassen!
Es liegt weder an der Technik noch der AtmosphÃ¤re, das ist soweit Top und macht optisch wirklich etwas her. Die Beleuchtung, die riesigen SchwÃ¤rme , die Kulisse, alles sehr schick..ABER...

Diese Spiel schwÃ¤chelt meiner Meinung nach am Kampfsystem, und das , wo es doch ein Action Game sein soll...
Der gesamte Kampf wirkt einfach extrem "schwammig". Man prÃ¼gelt wie wild, ohne jeden Sinn und Verstand drauf los. Treffer hagelt es von allen Seiten so das mann zeitweise nichts anderes tun kann auÃŸer permanent die Leertaste zu spammen. Man hat zu keiner Zeit das GefÃ¼hl irgendwie wirklich Einfluss auf den Kampf zu haben ob man nun gut oder schlecht spielt! Es hagelt einen Treffer nach dem anderen und es gibt eigentlich nichts was man dagegen tun kÃ¶nnte. Gelegentlich, wenn man es denn in dem ganzen Gewusel mitbekommt, kann man mal einen Block raushauen. Hier wirkt das ganze dann auch wuchtig, geht jedoch in dem ganzen durcheinander vÃ¶llig unter.
Ich habe es auf Schwer und Leicht gespielt, und vÃ¶llig Wurst ob man sich gut oder schlecht anstellt...irgendwie kommt man schon durch! Das erfordert keinerlei KÃ¶nnen oder Raffinesse sonder ist schlichtes TastengehÃ¤mmere!

Beim ersten Teil war auch ordentlich was los auf den Schlachtfeldern, aber wenn ich hier meine Attacken und Finisher gut getimt habe, hatt ich Einfluss darauf wie sich der Kampf entwickelt! KÃ¤mpfte ich schnell, nutzte BetÃ¤ubungsschlÃ¤ge konnte ich lÃ¤nger im Kampf bestehen und letzten Endes den Kampf fÃ¼r mich entscheiden!

Hier ist es vÃ¶llig egal wie ich kÃ¤mpfe, die Treffer kassiere ich so oder so, dann gibt es alle paar Sekunden mal eine Konterattacke und einen Finisher der sich jedoch extrem schnell abnutzt. Diese Konter sind auch das einzige was man wirklich in der Hand hat. 95% der Treffer kassiert man trotzdem ob man nun geschickt ausweicht oder nicht und am Ende kommt man dann so oder so durch den Kampf ohne eigentlich zu wissen wie!

Die KÃ¤mpfe sind schlicht viel zu unÃ¼bersichtlich und man haut einfach wild drauf los mit immer und immer und immer......und immer den selben stumpfen Attacken! Wenn man sich einem grÃ¶ÃŸeren Gegner stellt wird man in der Zeit hundert mal von hinten getroffen von Hormaganten die einfach stumpf an deiner Figur "kleben" .Die stehen einfach dumm da und man verliert Leben und RÃ¼stung ohne etwas dagegen unternehmen zu kÃ¶nnen !
Die SchlÃ¤ge sind extrem unprÃ¤zise und gehen allzu oft ins Leere. Der Marine stapft dabei einfach schwerfÃ¤llig vorwÃ¤rts und haut ein und dieselbe Kombo nach der anderen raus .

Posted: September 10
Ended friendship with Helldivers 2.

Space Marine 2 is my new best friend.

Posted: September 28
Product received for free

This review is based on a review copy played on both PC and Steam Deck.

Overview
(In-depth analysis below)
Space Marine 2 is an exhilarating sequel that nails fast-paced hybrid combat, mixing ranged and close-quarters as you take on endless hordes of Tyranids. With a massive selection of weapons and gameplay mechanics, each encounter feels not only unique but incredibly intense and satisfying. Despite some optimization hiccups, it is still an incredible journey through the dark and gritty Warhammer 40k universe. Whether a long-time fan or new to the franchise, there is plenty to enjoy.

Positives Negatives
















The story picks up one century after the first installment. Titus now leads a squad of Ultramarines in a relentless battle against the Tyranids, a deadly alien swarm threatening humanity. However, Titus' return is clouded by suspicionâ€”once accused of Chaos corruption, his every decision is scrutinized, and trust in his leadership is shaky at best. But as the Tyranid menace grows, survival demands action, leaving little room for doubt or hesitation.

The narrative intertwines high-stakes action with personal drama, as the urgent need to confront a devastating foe clashes with the lingering mistrust surrounding Titus' past. This completes a compelling tale of exoneration, loyalty, and relentless warfare, absorbing you in the adrenaline of battle and the depth of Titus' journey.


SM2 builds on Saber Interactive's signature horde mechanics from World War Z, refining the formula to fit within the chaotic, action-packed Warhammer 40k universe.
The extensive arsenal of weapons offers diverse gameplay mechanics that can alter your playstyle significantly, capturing the visceral intensity of 40k battles with brutal executions and massive gunfights against swarms of enemies. Though a few quirky design choices from WWZ persist, like the absence of jumping, long button presses for actions, and lackluster AI companions that cannot be adjusted, these qualms of mine are minor in the bigger picture. The overall experience remains highly engaging, fluid, and, most importantly, fun.

Each Tyranid has unique abilities and attack patterns, meaning you cannot just rely on the same strategy for every encounter; you'll need to adapt your approach as new threats are introduced. This keeps the horde mechanics fresh with increasingly complex enemy variations. Boss fights are particularly thrilling, often demanding quick thinking and precise movement, and are a welcome change of pace.

Mobility plays a crucial role, and much like weaponry and combat, it feels fantastic. You can sense the weight of the hefty armor, making traversal satisfyingâ€”especially when utilizing mobility-orientated abilities like the jetpack. However, the absence of a cover system or the mere ability to jump forces you to rely on frantic dodge-rolling and the riposte mechanic to avoid being overwhelmed amidst the hordes you face; while fun at first it can become quite repetitive.


Alongside the already impressive campaign, additional game modes are available at your leisure that can be enjoyed alone or with your fellow brothers. The Operations mode offers supplementary missions set between the campaign events, where you can choose from six classes, each with unique playstyles, loadouts, and abilities. Completing Operations rewards you with XP, unlocking new weapons, class, and weaponry upgrades, and the ability to customize your Space Marine. Lastly, Eternal War presents a 6v6 multiplayer mode where you can test your skills against others in the name of the Emperor if a competitive thrill is what you desire.

Altogether, SM2 offers a wealth of content, from raw content alone and experimentation across different classes and weapons extending replayability, with a solid sense of progression and customization. Plus, Saber has already released a robust roadmap, promising even more future content, both free and paid.



The environments span towering Gothic cathedrals and industrial wastelands to the desolate expanse of space, each grand in size and detail. The battle-scarred power armor of the Space Marines and array of weapons are rendered in striking detail, a sharp contrast to the grotesque, bio-engineered forms of the Tyranids, all of which soaked in the oppressive atmosphere of unending war, heightening the tension and chaos of combat. With dynamic lighting, explosive effects, and visceral melee animations, every visual element enhances the epic struggle for survival that is Warhammer 40k.


The audio design as a whole is superb, with each weapon producing a distinctive, hefty auditory punch that highlights their power and impact in combat. This is further complemented by immersive ambient battlefield sounds and compelling voice acting, creating a rich and engaging auditory landscape. The OST is exceptional, greatly enriching the overall experience. It features a mix of intense, atmospheric, orchestral arrangements to craft a dynamic soundtrack that adapts seamlessly to the gameplay, heightening emotional tension during intense battles, and even the calmer moments.

Posted: September 13
This game has many strengths but unfortunately fails in the most crucial aspect........the combat.

Playing on veteran (intended difficulty) fails as delivering the power fantasy of mowing down hordes of foes and brutally destroying worthy foes with consummate skill. The armour generating mechanic works but even horde enemies do so much damage it is often depleted immediately. The health regen mechanic just doesn't work - constantly getting downed, scrounging for medicae packs and spamming ultimate ability as much as possible just get some health back the core game play loop. Titus feel sluggish and the enemies are too bullet spongy. The combat just feels 'off'.

That being said, as a huge Warhammer fan, I loved the graphics, voice acting, musical score and the atmosphere of the game.

Just a shame about the actual game play loop.

Only get if you love 40k enough to overlook the flaws.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Review
DespuÃ©s de muchos aÃ±os desde el lanzamiento de la acciÃ³n original de los Marines Espaciales del mundo futurista de Warhammer, la secuela ha llegado. Te llena de adrenalina, pero tambiÃ©n puede traer la frustraciÃ³n de morir a menudo. Afortunadamente, no tienes que estar solo para luchar contra las hordas enemigas, y en compaÃ±Ã­a de amigos, tus posibilidades de tener Ã©xito y, sobre todo, de sobrevivir son mayores.

El personaje principal es el marine espacial Demetrian Titus, que era el personaje central de la primera parte y entonces todavÃ­a era capitÃ¡n. DespuÃ©s de ser acusado injustamente de corrupciÃ³n, es reasignado a la acciÃ³n, pero despuÃ©s de ser degradado con el rango de teniente. DespuÃ©s del desembarco de entrenamiento al comienzo de la campaÃ±a, ya no lucha solo, sino en compaÃ±Ã­a de los marines Chairon y Gadriel. Al jugar solo, sus roles serÃ¡n asumidos por bots, que pueden luchar decentemente y te revivirÃ¡n cuando sea necesario, pero no puedes dirigir sus acciones y no esperes una cooperaciÃ³n mÃ¡s cercana. Afortunadamente, puedes reemplazarlos invitando a otros jugadores antes de ingresar a una nueva misiÃ³n.

Directamente durante la campaÃ±a en la base, desde donde te transportan al Ã¡rea de la misiÃ³n, puedes saltar y jugar operaciones PvE separadas o enfrentarte a otros jugadores en el modo PvP de Eternal War con los objetivos de capturar territorios, capturar con control y aniquilaciÃ³n. Sin embargo, dado que recibimos el juego antes del lanzamiento, fue prÃ¡cticamente imposible encontrar oponentes vivos, pero al menos tuvimos suerte en las operaciones.

La ventaja de la campaÃ±a es la elecciÃ³n de la dificultad y el guardado automÃ¡tico del progreso en los puntos de control. Entonces, despuÃ©s de agotar las vidas o el nÃºmero de resurrecciones cuando caigas, continuarÃ¡s desde el Ãºltimo punto de control. Por el contrario, cada operaciÃ³n termina inmediatamente despuÃ©s de tu muerte (cuando progresas con compaÃ±eros de equipo en vivo despuÃ©s de la muerte de todo el equipo) y luego debes volver a pasar por todo de nuevo. AdemÃ¡s, las operaciones son bastante difÃ­ciles y no llegarÃ¡s muy lejos con los bots, aunque suelen revivirte.

Por otro lado, en las operaciones, puedes elegir la clase de tu personaje: hay seis de ellos para elegir, desde tÃ¡ctico, pasando por francotirador, hasta pesado. Incluso si fallas, ganas experiencia, niveles y nuevas ventajas por separado con cada enfoque utilizado. Aunque solo uno de ellos puede estar activo, pero definitivamente beneficioso en combate. AdemÃ¡s, puedes cambiar de equipo en la armerÃ­a de la base, donde desbloqueas nuevas armas, asÃ­ como sus variaciones avanzadas. AdemÃ¡s, puede personalizar la apariencia y las partes individuales de su cuerpo: casco, charreteras, placa pectoral, etc.

Lo interesante de las operaciones es que complementan la trama de la campaÃ±a, pero no es necesario pasar por ellas. Por ejemplo, sucede que Titus y su equipo deben cumplir el objetivo principal en el planeta, y al mismo tiempo otros tres marines deben llevar a cabo una acciÃ³n de distracciÃ³n de apoyo. El paso de Titus es necesario para la continuaciÃ³n de la campaÃ±a, pero puedes ignorar la acciÃ³n de distracciÃ³n o jugarlo en cualquier momento como parte de las operaciones.

En las misiones, progresas en diferentes entornos, tanto en interiores como en exteriores, pero siempre es una forma de corredor. Por lo tanto, solo puedes caminar por las calles demarcadas y no tienes la oportunidad de moverte libremente por la zona. Los objetivos son inicialmente bastante diversos, pero luego se repiten. Probablemente la mÃ¡s interesante es la protecciÃ³n de las cadenas de los ascensores o transmisores que intentan comerse a las criaturas voladoras. En el camino, recolectas municiones y equipo adicional, puedes cambiar de arma en los puestos. En lugares predeterminados, interactuarÃ¡ con los objetos seleccionados. Utiliza interruptores para activar mecanismos, abrir puertas o arrancar el ascensor, romper una barrera, etc.

Puede tener dos armas con usted, una de las cuales es un arma de mano mÃ¡s pequeÃ±a y, ademÃ¡s de ellas, tambiÃ©n un cuchillo, un martillo o una espada de energÃ­a. Al disparar, puede usar el zoom, donde la cÃ¡mara cambia de la vista en tercera persona a la primera persona y puede enfocar el objetivo con mayor precisiÃ³n, o incluso cambiar los modos de arma. En el combate a larga distancia, usarÃ¡s diferentes rifles y metralletas con diferente alcance, precisiÃ³n y cadencia. Sin embargo, la municiÃ³n debe usarse con prudencia, porque es bastante limitada y los suministros no siempre estÃ¡n a mano.

En los ataques cuerpo a cuerpo, literalmente cortarÃ¡s todo y usarÃ¡s ataques de Ã¡rea mÃ¡s fuertes, que son un placer para diezmar a los tirÃ¡nidos. Finalmente, cuando la vÃ­ctima estÃ¡ temporalmente inmovilizada y se ilumina en rojo, para poder ejecutarlos. Las ejecuciones no solo son impresionantes a la vista, sino que tambiÃ©n complementan instantÃ¡neamente algunas de tus armaduras. Se agota cuando se daÃ±a, y luego los enemigos te quitan la salud. Esto se puede restaurar parcialmente, pero usarÃ¡ estimulantes para una recuperaciÃ³n rÃ¡pida. Otro accesorio Ãºtil son las granadas.

Space Marine tiene grÃ¡ficos decentes con soporte DLSS y efectos y componentes estÃ¡ndar. La apariencia es agradable, principalmente debido al gran diseÃ±o de los sitios con atenciÃ³n al detalle. Se trata de hermosas vistas, por ejemplo, de una base militar, donde, ademÃ¡s de tu equipo, tambiÃ©n puedes ver a otros secuaces y unidades del emperador disparando a hordas de tirÃ¡nidos que se ciernen a lo lejos. Y cuando saltas a la acciÃ³n y eres asistido por un tanque, la atmÃ³sfera y la experiencia de combate son muy intensas. Sin mencionar que los fanÃ¡ticos acÃ©rrimos del universo de Warhammer 40K tambiÃ©n deben estar muy impresionados por los elementos autÃ©nticos, el procesamiento de armaduras, unidades y estructuras.

Space Marine 2, para un fan de Warhammer 40,000, es un sueÃ±o hecho realidad. Aunque no hace falta ser un Ã¡vido fan o haber jugado al capÃ­tulo anterior para apreciar el juego, lo cierto es que se ha hecho con el debido cuidado pensando en las personas que aman la franquicia y les habla con referencias muy especÃ­ficas y con algunas sorpresas. Con Space Marine 2 puedes esperar una acciÃ³n de pasillo sencilla con hectolitros de sangre, ubicaciones bien diseÃ±adas del universo de Warhammer 40,000 y mucha diversiÃ³n en compaÃ±Ã­a de otros jugadores. Al jugar en solitario, puedes disfrutar de unas 10-12 horas de campaÃ±a con una historia, pero el resto es casi injugable sin compaÃ±eros en vivo, aunque se pueden usar bots. Las operaciones cooperativas con amigos son excelentes, adrenalina, sin ellos aburrimiento y muerte rÃ¡pida. Y PvP es para medir las fortalezas y habilidades de los demÃ¡s. Por lo tanto, Space Marines 2 sobresale en el avance en modo cooperativo y la campaÃ±a tampoco se puede desperdiciar y no tienes que haber crecido en Warhammer para disfrutarlo..

La campagne est un chef d'oeuvre, le mode PVE et PVP sont tres tres bon et on ne s'ennui pas. Toujours quelque chose a faire, a dÃ©bloquer etc...

Pour ce qui est de l'optimisation.
Elle est bonne, ceux qui s'en plaignent, j'ai du mal a comprendre.
La Gameplay est jouissif sans etre redondant
Les OST sont excellente, mais pas memorable
La campagne est courte, mais pour le coup EPIC
La Custom est aboutie, hate de voir la battlepass et les DLC a venir

En bref, aucun regret d'avoirs mis 90 euros. J'ai rarement Ã©tÃ© aussi content d'un achat videoludique. Si Focus et Saber font un suivi actif du jeu avec des ajouts important niveau custom, ennemi et niveau. Ca sera un EXCELLENT jeu qui a de longues annÃ©es devant lui
Sur ce je retourne monter mon Bulwark Imperial Fist

(Au passage, faites le jeu en VO, sous titre francais, la VO est EXCELLENTE)

Posted: September 14
I want to recommend this game, I really do. But this is not an $80 game. Campaign took 5 hours, good story. Gameplay feels good, graphics are great. PvE is garbage right now, servers crap out on you. Just spent almost 2 hours trying to queue for a match and every time I got in it would disconnect me. I only made it into an actual game once, I killed two Rubric Marines and then was disconnected. PvP doesn't appeal to me so I haven't tried that, and likely won't.

I want more value from an $80 game than a 5hr campaign and a multiplayer that doesn't work. And they want seasons on top of that, slowly trickle out content that might have made this an $80 game over the next few years. If you can pick this up for half price or lower then you should grab this game, or maybe wait a year or two for the content to catch up to the price.

Posted: September 6
Als Fan des Warhammer 40K-Universums war ich von Space Marine 2 sofort gefesselt. Das Spiel bringt all das mit, was ich an diesem dÃ¼steren und brutalen Universum liebe: groÃŸartige Grafik, flÃ¼ssige Performance und eine packende AtmosphÃ¤re, die mich voll in die Schlachten des 41. Jahrtausends eintauchen lÃ¤sst.

Grafik â€?Eine beeindruckende Reise ins Chaos

Die Grafik ist schlichtweg atemberaubend. Von den detaillierten RÃ¼stungen der Space Marines bis zu den schier endlosen Horden der Tyraniden â€?jedes Modell ist ein visuelles Highlight. Die Umgebungen sind dÃ¼ster und episch zugleich, genau wie man es von Warhammer 40K erwartet. Besonders beeindruckend fand ich, wie die Explosionen und KÃ¤mpfe visuell eingefangen wurden. Jeder Treffer hat Wucht, jede Explosion lÃ¤sst den Bildschirm erzittern, und die Schlachtfelder verwandeln sich schnell in Ruinen. Es ist, als wÃ¼rde man mitten in einer Schlacht stehen.

Performance â€?FlÃ¼ssig, auch wenn es hektisch wird

Selbst bei den grÃ¶ÃŸten Schlachten bleibt die Performance stabil. Ich hatte keine EinbrÃ¼che in der Bildrate, auch wenn Dutzende von Tyraniden auf dem Bildschirm wÃ¼teten. Das Spiel lÃ¤uft bemerkenswert flÃ¼ssig und zeigt, wie gut optimiert es ist. Besonders beeindruckend ist, wie es selbst auf mittleren Systemen stabil lÃ¤uft, ohne an visueller QualitÃ¤t zu verlieren.

SpielgefÃ¼hl â€?Intensiv und brachial

Was mir besonders gefallen hat, ist das GefÃ¼hl, tatsÃ¤chlich ein Space Marine zu sein. Space Marine 2 schafft es, die Wucht und StÃ¤rke eines Ultramarines perfekt zu vermitteln. Jede Nahkampfatacke fÃ¼hlt sich wuchtig an, und die Bolter-SchÃ¼sse haben einen befriedigenden Klang. Man hat das GefÃ¼hl, unaufhaltsam durch die Feinde zu pflÃ¼gen â€?und genau so soll es sein! Die Steuerung ist dabei intuitiv und flÃ¼ssig, sodass es SpaÃŸ macht, durch die gegnerischen Horden zu wÃ¼ten.

AtmosphÃ¤re â€?Das 41. Jahrtausend zum Leben erweckt

Space Marine 2 fÃ¤ngt die dÃ¼stere AtmosphÃ¤re des Warhammer 40K-Universums perfekt ein. Die BrutalitÃ¤t, die Hoffnungslosigkeit und die stÃ¤ndige Bedrohung durch die Tyraniden sind in jedem Moment spÃ¼rbar. Der Soundtrack und die GerÃ¤uscheffekte tragen zur Immersion bei â€?von donnernden Explosionen bis zum furchteinflÃ¶ÃŸenden BrÃ¼llen der Feinde. Man fÃ¼hlt sich wirklich, als kÃ¤mpfe man um das Ãœberleben der Menschheit.

Fazit â€?Ein Muss fÃ¼r 40K-Fans

Space Marine 2 ist ein intensives, visuell beeindruckendes Erlebnis. Es fÃ¤ngt die AtmosphÃ¤re des Warhammer 40K-Universums perfekt ein und bietet eine flÃ¼ssige, kraftvolle Spielerfahrung. FÃ¼r Fans von Warhammer 40K ist dieses Spiel ein Muss!

Posted: September 27
The game is fun.
What's not fun is waiting over twenty minutes for the game to start. All it does after the patch (and most times prior to patch) is sit at a black screen and won't load beyond that.
I'm less concerned with keeping the game balanced and more about the ability to play it at all.

Posted: September 16
Space Marine 2 macht SpaÃŸ und hÃ¤lt sich einigermaÃŸen gut an die Vorlagen und schlieÃŸt gut an den ersten Teil an. Die Kampagne sieht gut aus und hÃ¶rt sich gut an und das SpielgefÃ¼hl insgesamt ist solide. Die Koop Missionen sind spaÃŸig aber insgesamt kurzweilig, da wird ja aber noch nachgereicht. Der Multiplayer ist bisher leider echt mies. PersÃ¶nlich finde ich die Steuerung auch nicht wirklich gut, kann aber auch verstehen, dass es kompliziert ist bei 2 verschiedenen Main Waffen, die gleichzeitig zum Einsatz kommen. Die meisten Spieler verhalten sich wie absolute Bots, der Sound ist gedÃ¤mpft und die Maps sind super langweilig. Fans von 40k und Shooter fans werden aber zufriedengestellt.

Posted: November 8
Great game, combat feels heavy, which I absolutely love, but I cannot understand the "balancing". Half of the map I have to run without any ammo left in my weapons and god forbid a mini-boss spawns because I'll be running be into the previous sector, if I could, but most of the time it is locked off already as "the point of no return". Having no ammo doesn't make the game more "challenging", just more frustrating. I'm sorry that I'm trying to have fun in a shooter game by using my weapons and ammo.

Posted: November 30
An absolutely brilliant game, that really encapsulates the feeling of the bulk of a Space Marine. You get the feeling of sense and bulk, which is not always present in depictions of Space Marines.

While there were initially issues with PvE missions not starting, these were fixed quickly. Gameplay, visual design and sound design are all great. A worthy successor to Space Marine I, and definitely my pick for GOTY.

column2: AT THIS TIME. Campaign story writing is amazing
column3: 10/10. But gameplay? solid 6/10. Feels very slow and clunky. Sort of how i imagine fighting in a giant metal suit of armour would actually be. You might be a tank but you're a slow tank with very delayed mobility. You can roll
column4: but enjoy the 4 business days before it works. Furthermore
column5: 8 hours in 2024 to beat a campaign? Felt very rushed. Six Operations that tie in to the campaign
column6: again clunky but gun play feels good. But the disconnects every few games and the hackers on day 1 make that a moot point. More so
column7: there's 3 game modes with a couple maps. It gets very repetitive very fast. Definitely not enough content to be a triple A game with triple A pricing."

The game developers actually care and listen to us. I highly recommend this game

column1: Brilliant Single player campaign where you get fun weapons and a rough story to simply frame killing termanids and chaos marines.
Someone with literally no knowledge of the lore I really enjoyed it and would consider myself somewhat a fan.
Performance is tight and ran great
column2: played on a mix of PS5 and PC and just finished it up on my ROG Ally X which also ran it great.
just buy the game youll love it!"

column5:
Posted: October 20
Edit 10/28/2024 - Patch 4.0 rolled back some of the..worst changes. However, Chaos is still incredibly unfun to fight for the below reasons. They mention things like win percentages, but I wonder if that's Chaos and Tyranid missions lumped together. The buffs to bolters are..lackluster. They still remain the option for someone wanting to shoot themselves in the foot. I'll mark it recommended but hestitantly.

I won't lie. It was pretty bearable at release but.. I don't really know what the devs are doing in regards to balance and I don't think they know either. Everything I'm about to write is taken from someone who runs 90% difficulty 4 of 5 (Ruthless) and has their survivor helmet from the Lethal (5/5) missions. And this is all for PVE only.

They've done balance passes nerfing the damage on weapons when most of the weapons are already pretty bad.

Chaos majoris are the examplars of this poor design. They can teleport around in an instant. You will need to do about a dozen or two full melee combos to down them but, they can teleport away without warning.

The flamer chaos marines are the worst of the worst. They can teleport without warning in the middle of your combo, charge up a dodge only attack while you're still in an animation that you can't animation cancel out of, and reduce your armor and a good chunk of your HP near instantly. Even if they don't teleport, your dodge roll is shorter than the AOE ring you need to flee from but you won't have time to do the second dodge roll before you're hit. They have incredible range but that doesn't matter because, again, they can teleport to you.

And you may think the answer is a gun. But because the guns have been near nerfed into the ground - you will need to spend multiple magazines per marine.

And they did do a patch that made fighting chaos ... not so bad. And then immediately rolled that back partially and amped up the grind by making us worse at fighting into it.

It's starting to feel that a very vocal minority of players at the upper band of skill levels are dictating the required skill level of all the average skill level players.

For He is the light of Mankind.His is the one truth in a galaxy of falsity and horror.
Those that defy His will shall be cut down in swaths.
Their armies crushed, their tainted lands burned to ash and their wretched kind eradicated from existence.
Now go forth and lay waste to the xenos plague, in the name of the Emperor.

Posted: September 10
I've only ever dipped my toes in the Warhammer universe, mostly through my friends hobbies and other games based in the universe such as darktide or inquisitor martyr. Despite having little knowledge I thoroughly enjoyed the campaign and felt invested in Titus's story, the gameplay is fairly solid but nothing revolutionary and the game in it's current state is a good base with some content but more importantly it has great potential to be built on. I look forward to playing more and seeing what comes to the game in future!

Posted: September 7
The game is Warhammer 40K through and through. Grim, Dark and gritty.

The story is good and introduces you to why Titus got turned into a Primaris well.
For the obvious culture war question: No, it is not "woke".

Combat is violent and satisfying. A similar experience to what I recently had with Batman Arkham Knight. It is challenging.
(Countering, dodging and learning patterns etc, but it is more simplified here).
When you play as Titus you FEEL like a Space Marine. The power of the melee attacks, ripping enemies limb from limb. The shaking footsteps where you can 'feel' the weight behind every step. The thunderous boom as so much armour, meat, bone and muscle hits the ground after jumping down a ledge.

Started the game on hardest difficulty, and it is very challenging. Still determining if it will be possible to finish playing solo with bots. Edit: Seems possible, but is very challenging. Would only suggest "Angel of death" difficulty for the most dedicated players.

Shooting is also satisfying, but can't be completely relied on, engaging in melee is nearly mandatory once swarms close in.

Visuals are very impressive and faithfully 40K.

Sounds are all great and when involved in fighting give you the feeling you are in a battle.
Music is dark and 100% fits 40K theme. The main theme when the game starts actually sent chills down my back. (Awe inspiring).

After a quick look, operations and Endless War mode will provide plenty of replay opportunity.
Edit: Operations is thoroughly enjoyable. Levelling up is fun and very satisfying to become more powerful with more perks, better weapons and the armour skins are beautiful. The artists REALLY put effort into them!

On technical and performance, the game is running beautifully. RTX 3060, I7-10700K, 32GB RAM, SSD, Windows 11. Ultra settings, native resolution @ 1080P with TAA gives 40-60 frames. Lowest frames I've experienced so far are 30 in graphically intensive portions. (Considering my hardware is not high end, the performance was surprising to me, it shows the game is well optimised in my opinion).

The game practically oozes all the effort and work the developers put into the game and definitely worth any 40K fan's attention.

Some are saying it has Epic. The game makes use of Epic online services. (Not an app, just core components that allow crossplay between Steam and Epic as well as the needed files for Easy Anti Cheat. No Epic account was required when I started the game and none created that I am aware of).

A couple of technical issues I can't figure out, sometimes voice lines are normal, then barely audible (with subtitles it isn't too much of a problem, but if playing without them you strain to hear them.)

The most glaring problem is that the so called anti-cheat is doing nothing to keep cheaters out from ruining the game for others. That alone is enough to spoil the entire experience in PVE and PVP.

Couldn't join a friend in campaign and still looking for a solution. (Will update review if I find one or find the cause). Edit: I was able to join friends today with a few retry attempts, but connecting isn't reliable and sometimes doesn't work. Edit #2: Connection much better. Regularly join with friends now and only disconnections now and then.

Edit: No crashes or glitches thus far with exception that sometimes a save seems to glitch out and you restart a checkpoint with lower ammo, different primary than the one you chose along the mission, meds and health than you had when you reached the checkpoint. (This happened to me on "Severance" mission when mobbing me. Unknown what exactly happens to cause the glitch.

Posted: September 16
My initial thoughts were that the game is an improvement in every conceivable way over the first one. It obviously looks better, has more combat mechanics, more equipment, additional gameplay modes. However the more I think about the game and try to engage with its mechanics the more frustrating it becomes. At this point in time I only recommend buying this on a sale of at least 30% if not more.

At this moment the game is significantly overpriced for what little it offers.
The campaign is short and looks extremely cool.
PvE has six linear maps in total, each is completed in about 25 minutes or less.
PvP I haven't played because despite there being an anti cheat there are plenty of cheaters anyway.
Congrats on wasting money on EAC.

The visuals are amazing. They are the best part of the game. I know the visuals and assets for the game were incredibly expensive (they look the part) and therefore there isn't that much content, but I wish the gameplay came first. But it truly looks absolutely amazing.

The gameplay, sadly, comes far behind the visuals. At the moment it can be downright painful at times.
I spent the majority of my time thus far in PvE (online coop). My problems with it are as follows:

Class lock in PvE feels awful. You cannot play with a full squad of tactical/devastator/assault. I'm not sure what came first, the idea for class lock and then they decided to make each character "unique" to compensate or whether it was the other way around. Anyway it doesn't feel good to be restricted in this way in a game that has so little content to do.
The voice lines attached to each character aren't even that hyperspecific to their class, they would be passable on other classes.

Enemies have mile long healthbars. Knowing the lore it makes sense to me (in particular for larger tyranid gribblies and Tsons) but with how its done in the game it makes combat feel like a chore at times. You just keep shooting your gun or wailing on an enemy with your melee weapon and its not having any noticeable effect other than vfx/sparks (which look nice).
The majoris+ enemies should have more flinch/stagger animations at least when getting shot.
I think its a miss to not add some sort of battle damage system where nids get their limbs hacked/blown off but keep coming at you. The Tsons could have ceramite, adamantium and engravings getting shorn off their armor from bolter fire.
In fact it would be cool if we could shoot off the guns off ranged enemies.

Just something that shows the player "this guy is taking damage", not just particle effects.
Small enemies have the beginning of this system, but it doesn't feel right.
Shooting a termagant for it to reset the 1st frame of the same "owie I'm hit" animation 6 times in a row makes me feel like my weapon is either a nerf gun or downright bugged.

Its extremely disappointing with how little damage melee weapons deal. The finishers and their animations are extremely cool, I wish there were more and changed with direction you approach an enemy, like in Doom 2016/eternal. I also wish I could decide whether my marine does a hand-to-hand finisher or uses his weapon to do it.
However taking several swings at a termagant/tzaangor with a thunder hammer only for it to keep fighting just feels bad.

The melee feels inconsistent in most situations. Parry and dodge sometimes just don't work, or possibly due to nearby enemies overlapping their attacks when close to you they force you to miss the parry and dodge window. Then you get stuck in the block animation (where at first you don't take damage) but you can't input any command, and then another comes in and keeps you stunlocked and makes you lose majority of your health.

The worst parts of melee is when you are in a crowd and get attacked by lots of small enemies - hormogants or tzaangors. Their attacks come out very fast and overlap and clip through each other, either forcing you to miss the parry window on the warrior/Tson and you block and then take damage, or you just whiff the parry and take damage anyway. Let me dodge/step out of a parry animation please.

Enemies have iframes on their dodges. It feels like you're being cheated out of what little damage you can put out.

The gunstrike is way too slow and I died multiple times while locked in the animation. Its generally a theme for how deaths happen in the game, you get stuck in some sort of animation/stagger you have no way of cancelling or getting out of and then you die.

The jump pack makes me very sad. In the campaign it worked just fine, but it is gutted in PvE.
Lets say you want to jump over a chasm or from one walkway to another, but they are separated by about 2 meters of empty space.
The game seems to draw a line from the base of your character and directly in front of a him. That line must be drawn over terrain you can walk on.
If that line encounters impassable terrain, such as a small safety barrier or a gap, in 90% of situations you can't jump over the barrier or that gap. So you see a distance you are certain you can jump over, you could walk to your target (so you know you should be able to jump there), but the game just doesn't let you. In addition, sometimes when the jump indicator (at the end of the line being drawn mentioned above) hits or collides with certain objects, the jump just won't activate. It just feels very janky and unsatisfying to use.

Now when you jump up, you can do a slam attack where the marine flies at high speed to the target on the ground.
You'd think the victim of that attack would get turned to paste after getting hit.
Nope. They just get staggered a bit.
In addition, during your slam attack you first hover midair "charging" the attack. This looks weird and should be removed, if anything the marine at the apex of the jump should slow down a bit, but not become stationary, and as gravity pulls him down he uses the jump pack to get more speed. Also during that little hover I get hit by melee attacks which shouldn't be able to reach me.

It feels incredibly unsatisfying, in particular with how long the cooldown is on the jump. With how little height you get from the jump I think it would be better if instead of a slam attack, it was a targeted charge where there is only 1 target (no AoE), but that target takes lots of damage and likely dies. That and also the marine hits the target with his weapon, not slams it into the ground. Also the jump pack should be the go to choice for tackling flying enemies (zoanthropes, levitating sorcerers), but there is no such option, You can either do a dash on the ground, jump from A to B, or jump and do a ground slam. There is a cutscene in the campaign that shows exactly how a jump pack should feel (it looks a bit OP there I'll admit, but it looks insanely fun) but having seen it and then trying the jump pack for yourself feels like you got cheated.

The ranged combat suffers from the same principal issue as melee - you just don't feel like you're doing any damage or that enemies are at all affected by taking multiple headshots in a row.
I think its most telling that the most fun to be had was using the the underslung grenade launcher or the sniper las fusil and two or three shotting majoris enemies. The melta is excellent at staggering hordes and clearing smaller enemies and leaving the large guys to take care of - honestly this should be a flamer (which for some reason is absent from PvE) and the melta should have a smaller blast but be the choice weapon to deal with heavy armour as in the lore.
When you have strong weapons which have direct impact like the three I mentioned, the ranged combat felt good. However, 90% of the guns do not have such an impact and therefore feel like trash.

Additionally, the amount of spread would be fine for a standard human, but how can an astartes have this much inaccuracy and spread? It makes no sense to me, in particular when all enemies are great at leading the player.

Its all so tiresome.

column5: en

Posted: November 28
Space Marine 2 is a must-buy game that harkens back to the politics-free heyday of gaming. It is like taking a time machine back to the 2010s and going through all those beautifully made games during that era. It also shows how far AAA gaming has fallen. All publishers and development teams should take note and do better, focusing primarily on player experience over 'sending the message' and monetization. Saber Interactive should be very proud of what they have made.

If, like me, you are disappointed with the needless disrespect towards canon and established lore by Games Workshop lately, then you need not fear Space Marine 2. Space Marine 2 follows the story of Captain Titus in a way that respects what has been and does not cater to the tourists and nu-Warhammer fans destroying the hobby currently. Any true Warhammer fans can buy Space Marine 2 guilt-free.

The single-player campaign is long enough to provide a story that ties into the Era Indomitus and the previous story of the first Space Marine game. Playing it solo can be challenging, especially on higher difficulties, but I found it to be well worth playing and had very few issues with it even though I finished it on early patches.

Playing Operations solo is also likewise a very meaningful experience that you cannot replicate elsewhere. I am ecstatic that Saber Interactive is continuing to develop more missions for this mode. The mission where you kill the Bio-Titan is my new favourite. I have had a few drops when I played it, but otherwise, I have not had any major issues.

Multiplayer is fun, but I still think the Bulwark class is overpowered, and some balancing is necessary. It is not a mode I have played a ton, but I can report no major issues.

A huge bonus is that the usual suspects hate Space Marine 2 and its success:



Another bonus is that the CEO of Saber Interactive is incredibly based:



As is some of their dev team:



I give Space Marine 2 a very solid 9/10, only citing some minor technical issues in Operations mode. Space Marine 2 is my game of the year this year on Steam, and I highly encourage anybody to buy it. Whether this is your first or tenth Warhammer game, this is a worthy buy and entry into the grimdark universe of 40k. Well done to Saber Interactive.
