Posted: September 10
Ich mÃ¶chte mit dem negativen beginnen. Der PVP und der PVE Modus haben meiner Meinung nach zu wenig Missionen bzw. Maps. Bei dem PVP Modus ist dies nicht so schlimm doch bei PVE geht die Lust leider nach den 6 Missionen schnell raus. Server Probleme gab es jedoch nicht viele. Einige haben Grafikprobleme und sehen unsichtbare Charaktere wo aber dran gearbeitet wird. Ich persÃ¶nlich hÃ¤tte mir gewÃ¼nscht das man seinen Space Marine individueller gestalten kann z.B. das man Namen, Stimme und Gesicht Ã¤ndern kann.

Der Rest an dem Spiel ist sehr positiv. Das Kampfsystem macht jedes mal Bock und auf die Grafik wÃ¤re sogar der Imperator stolz da sie sogar sehr flÃ¼ssig lÃ¤uft. Interface und Audio wirken sehr gut Ã¼berarbeitet und besonders die deutsche syncro kann sich durch aus hÃ¶ren lassen. Das absolute Highlight ist meiner Meinung nach die Kampagne. An der kann ich absolut nichts kritisieren da sie viel SpaÃŸ macht und die Inszenierung mehr als gut gelungen ist.

Mehr Content ist zwar bestÃ¤tigt durch die Roadmap aber ich glaube dieser wird dauern da der Content bestimmt zeitgleich mit den Konsolen raus kommt. Wenn ihr auch PVP spielt kann euch das Game sehr lange fesseln!

Mein erster Livestream

Posted: September 30
Ich habe nach 10 Stunden die Kampagne durchgespielt und werde mich definitiv weiter an den anderen Spiel-Modi erfreuen. Ich bin selber kein groÃŸer Kenner des Universums, jedoch mag ich das Warhammer Franchise trotzdem, auch Warhammer Fantasy. Man muss jedoch kein Kenner sein, um das Spiel zu mÃ¶gen. Es erzÃ¤hlt eine coole Geschichte, die recht knackig gehalten ist.
Grafisch ist es einfach bombastisch. Alles wirkt over the top, wie man es von Warhammer erwarten wÃ¼rde.
Trotz das ich "nur" eine 3080 mit einem ryzen 9 5900x habe, lÃ¤uft das Spiel die meiste Zeit butterweich und ist sehr gut optimiert. Wer immer stabile FPS haben will, braucht hier aber schon eine 40er Karte, wenn man alles auf max spielen will.
Einziges Manko fÃ¼r mich war das Ende der Kampagne. Es war unfassbar gut inszeniert. Jedoch hat das Spiel einem hier doch etwas zu oft die Kontrolle weggenommen und war dadurch gefÃ¼hlt nur noch eine groÃŸe Cutscene.
Insgesamt jedoch ein sehr gutes Spiel und sein Geld wert und weiterer Content ist ja angekÃ¼ndigt.

Posted: September 23
Wait for sale
Campaign is fairly short (took us 8 hours including waiting on loading screens and connection issues)
Looks amazing, but each mission boils down to: go to a button, press a button and fight some enemies while lift/portal/whatever is opening up.
Marines do not feel that powerful, missions are just repeat of the same thing like 8 times. The game feels slightly unfinished currently, and I regret my purchase, at this moment

Space Marine 2 Ã¨ un'esperienza coinvolgente che riesce a catturare l'immaginazione anche di chi, come me, Ã¨ un neofita nell'universo di Warhammer. Non Ã¨ necessario conoscere la lore fino in fondo per avere una totale immersione di quest'avventura: Infatti, il gioco ti trascina in un mondo oscuro e devastato, dove vestire i panni di un possente Space Marine Ã¨ un'esperienza incredibilmente gratificante.

PRO:
Gameplay fluido e appagante: Combattere le orde Ã¨ soddisfacente, con un mix bilanciato tra brutalitÃ  corpo a corpo e sparatorie adrenaliniche. L'uso delle armi e delle abilitÃ  Ã¨ molto intuitivo e non richiede meccaniche impegnative.

ModalitÃ  cooperativa: Giocare con gli amici aggiunge una nota di maggiore divertimento e strategia in piÃ¹, perfetto per affrontare le missioni piÃ¹ impegnative.

Supporto post-lancio promettente: Con una community giÃ  appassionata all'universo di Warhammer e/o players neofiti che vogliono conoscere questo mondo, il potenziale di miglioramento puÃ² essere molto alto per futuri aggiornamenti, DLC e contenuti aggiuntivi.
CONTRO:
Esplorazione limitata e poche mappe realmente immersive: Personalmente, penso che il gioco sia spesso lineare e non hai la possibilitÃ  di esplorare liberamente l'ambiente circostante per scoprire segreti, dettagli aggiuntivi sulla lore o, piÃ¹ semplicemente, oggetti unici da collezionare. Per quanto riguarda gli scenari, invece, mi aspettavo che alcune mappe fossero piÃ¹ creepy e curate a un contesto Grimdark.

Posted: November 21
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a terrific third-person shooter with a compelling story, loads of weapons that are a blast to use, and a healthy variety of enemies to use them on. It once again borrows many of its ideas from the Gears of War series, but theyâ€™re good ideas, and Space Marine 2 does a fine job of making them its own. And while the Operations PvE mode that accompanies it doesnâ€™t currently offer enough to keep me coming back, the deep customization options for your Space Marine do look promising if itâ€™s supported in post-launch updates as planned. Besides, when youâ€™re eviscerating aliens on planets as pretty as these, itâ€™s hard not to leave satisfied.

Posted: October 23
Game looks amazing, and there are some impressive set pieces. The swarms look cool as hell. But the combat is just too simplistic and repetitive to play by myself. It's probably more fun if you have a crew to play with, or if you're already a fan of the universe.

Posted: October 21
2024 appears to be the year of excellent sequels. Started with Helldivers 2, ending with Space Marine 2 after a hiatus of 13 years.

This game does a great job of balancing rewarding high skill ceiling while being easy for anyone to pick up with how Combat flows. You also do not need to know anything about Warhammer 40,000 to play this game. There is plenty of call outs for 40K lore junkies to keep them invested while introducing new folks to the lore and setting of the Grim Darkness of the far Feature, where only War exists.

An easy recommend from me if my input is of any worth.

Tres bon jeu pour s'immerser dans le monde des Ultramarine au niveau de la campagne. Je vous conseil cependant de vous renseigner aussi sur le lore de Warhammer 40K qui est tres riche. Le gameplay est tres bien on a affaire a un 3rd person shooter, avec different type de classes tres interessante. Le jeu en pvp est tres bien balancer avec ses classes differente justement. Le mode operation est excellent et viens se combiner parfaitement avec l'histoire de la campagne. Je paye rarement des jeux plein prix mais celui la je ne l'es pas regrettÃ©.

Product received for free

By the emperor, this is a good ol game but be warned. the machine spirit embeded In this game is quite paticulair.

My cogitator is of quite high standards with an 4080 super and a Ryzen 7 9700, but still the machine spirit seaces to co-operate and crashes out doing the most mundane tasks like loading up a save file. not even the fixes given by other tech-priests seem to calm the machine spirit down.

with great sadness this game is unplayable for me now. still I'd recomend for who's game does work it is a might pice of art..

Disappointed and Embarrassed by the Update..

Please pull back the update and return with amour and weapons.

Posted: October 17
Beauty Without Depth: A Stunning Journey That Falls Short

Within its first hour, Space Marine 2 hits all the right notes and gets you pumped about the journey ahead. The first thing you notice is how magnificent the game looks and soundsâ€”not just on a technical level, but also in terms of art design. Iâ€™m glad that this aspect remains consistent until the end. However, in terms of gameplay, things are sadly not looking so good. At first, the combat feels crunchy and fast, almost like a third-person Doom, but as time goes on, the downsides become more pronounced than the positives. After only a couple of hours, you realize how restrictive the level and mission design is. Additionally, the encounters start to feel superficial due to the lackluster weapon design. Almost every encounter can be easily completed with any of the weapons, which lack identity; as a result, you, as the player, donâ€™t feel in control of the combatâ€”you just go with the flow, shooting mindlessly with a couple of melee combos and finishers here and there.

The story is mindbogglingly simple, but the performances are strong, so the game doesnâ€™t feel entirely lifeless in that regard. Itâ€™s also surprisingly a direct sequel, both in terms of story and spirit. Iâ€™m pleased that a change in development studio didnâ€™t result in a soft reboot.

All in all, Space Marine 2 is a marvelous technical and artistic achievement; however, it fails to deliver as a compelling video game. I have only played the single-player campaign, so everything I say is directed at that aspect.

Once this bug's resolved, I'll change this to a full review with a thumbs up.

Posted: October 11
I won't deny that Space Marine 2 has some awesome moments (namely, any time you perform an Execution) but it's developers make a lot of decisions that chip away at my patience or otherwise confound me. I'll put a full list below, but some of the major ones are just a lack of cross-class weapon availability, extremely stingy use of I-Frames in a game with a lot of animation locks, and gating progression behind forced difficulty increases.

I also don't like Classes, but that's entirely my preference and I understand that's just how Monetization has decided Modern Gaming is going to develop.

1. Every class should be able to use every sidearm. Canonically, these are all Ultramarines, so you can't use the excuse 'well, different chapters learn different skills!' they are all in the same Chapter, and while I can generally forgive things like Heavies not getting Melee Weapons or Snipers locked to Knives, this is one thing I take major issue with.
2. No Automatic Sidearm at Launch? My trigger finger is getting enough exercise to lift a Bolter Pistol, and I am not a fan. Please add a sidearm that I can hold down the trigger and spray into Tyranid hordes properly.
3. Experience and Currency rewards are absolutely pitiful on Minimal and Moderate. I often won't even be able to afford a Color Pack after a mission on those difficulties, nevermind weapons. I can forgive putting my nose to the grindstone for class experience, but considering that progression is tied to unlocking and mastering weapons (which requires currency to buy every version of a weapon) this isn't okay.
4. Far more egregious is that Artifact and Relic Artifact Data is locked behind Substantial and Ruthless Difficulties respectively. Do you want to progress past Tier 2 Weapons? Well, your options are A) Tryhard, or B) Uninstall.
5. Speaking of Armory Data, it's not guaranteed for completing the mission. One has to be found in the mission (it is guaranteed to spawn, but ) and the other is from bosses that potentially spawn in the mission (but are not guaranteed, and also might coincide with the Horde Timer.)
6. Certain areas are basically guaranteed to Horde, which works heavily against it. Decapitation's Chapel is the best case of this: You can fight a Horde right outside the transition door, kill every Tyranid, enter, miss and then have to fight It's an extremely confined area which makes it even worse.
7. I-Frames are only built into Executions, like five frames of a successful Parry, and half of your Dodge. Most animations otherwise don't even have Hyperarmor, meaning you can get knocked out of your Stim, or you can start a Gunstrike instead of Parry and then get stunlocked and destroyed.
8. Ai cannot be assigned classes in Private Lobbies, nor can they be assigned specific weapons.
9. It's freaking 2024 and Helldivers 2, allows full remapping of all buttons on both Keyboard and Controller, what excuse does Focus have that I can't manually map my Melee to B/Circle button?

Focus recently released PAtch 4.0, and after an extreme amount of backlash, released 4.1 which removed nearly everything we hated from 4.0 (which was basically the whole thing, minus the introduction of Lethal) so the Developers CAN change the game if we demand it enough, and very quickly too. I'll flip my thumb when they rework Armory Data though, because it's still â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ I have to play on Ruthless to upgrade my weapons to max.

Posted: October 7
The game is awesome.
Great story, nice campaign and very cool CO-OP. The PVP is kinda "ok", but could be better.
The major issue they need to fix is the constant disconnects during CO-OP missions. You can grind for 1 hour doing a mission, still there's a 50% chance of being disconnected out of nothing. Then, you get zero XP, zero progress, zero rewards. It's pure time wasted and back to the lobby. The worst part that IT MAY EVEN HAPPEN WHEN YOU ARE THE HOST, AND YOU ARE PLAYING ALONE. Crazy, right?

Posted: October 6
BUY THIS GAME.

People normally tell me, "You really do live in nostalgia". But after getting a bunch of my friends to buy this game and talk about it being a relief not to have to race through a battle pass and all the extra BS we are shoved in our face. it's a full game and dlc just adds icing onto this wonderfully made cake, nothing more. It truly feels like back in the golden age between 2001-2010.

Truly the Devs of this game cooked. Thank you Devs and by the Emperor, we will purge Xenos in GLORY

Posted: September 30
Wide as a puddle, deep as the same puddle, with more padding than a Primaris Power Armor, and yet only amounting to an 8-10 hour campaign with maybe 4 hours of actual gameplay.

Please don't buy this at full price.

This would be quite a neat, if dragging, experience for 15 bucks. Asking for 60, or even 90 or 100 bucks for this is, frankly, insulting and shows how desperate people are for good a 40k experience. Sadly, this one ain't it.

For what's actually in the campaign:

You're jumping in the role of a grumpy, whinging, military door technician role playing as one of the Emperor's Chosen. During your fights with all of 8 types of enemies the game has on offer, next to its 3 bosses, your main job is pressing door opening buttons waiting for elevators.

Combat difficulty mostly revolves around avoiding getting pelted by ranged combat damage while trying to get into melee range, where the spectacular takedown animations and the mini-cutscene camera work really shines. Melee combat is covered by invulnerability and regeneration granted by these extended animations, i-frames during dodges, and a parry window wider than the greatest stained-glass displays in the Cathedrals of Terra.

Between combat encounters, you're walking down narrow, samey corridors with a ton of buttons and objective markers. There is always one way forward and one little side area, sometimes two, that contain an extra med pack, ammo pack and combat boosts. But don't fear, there will be an objective marker at the ready telling you the way forward, and which button to press for the next line of stiff dialog.

The campaign is a formulaic low engagement spectacle, dragging from vista to vista, where the characters in the cutscenes get to have a lot more fun and do way cooler things than what you're allowed to do in game.

Your â€œalways ready for coopâ€?group of 3 Marines, with our main character Primaries Marine, the flanked the jealous upstart that we'll grow to love over the course of the move and the placeholder personality and is also around for other to say lines at.

These are not the transhuman weapons of destruction, sworn to the will of the Emperor, and imbued with their 22 or 19 gene-seed organs respectively. This is Sergeant Jake McMuricaMan and his squabbling Band of Brothers, more devoted to human infighting about rank and questing orders than to carry forward the will of the Emperor in their Call of Duty. The plot might as well stem from one of these shooters.

The combat loop, when the game actually hands over controls to you, is split up 2 to 4 minute encounters in a contained arena. Each fight is followed up by 3â€?0 minutes of walking around, watching cutscenes, holding â€œforwardâ€?while more drooling placeholder dialog dribbles as you press some elevator button, and then finally arriving at the next small combat scene. But not before you're promoted to press the ATTENTION button to make sure you're not missing the highly scripted vista waiting for you. This Disneyland approach to level design can work out great for spectacle fighters, or depending on the difficulty you pick, walking simulators, but falls flat here as there is no overarching narrative or story being progressed. Just another power generator that needs turning on, another door that needs opening, another obstacle to walk around. All while the most impactful and coolest moments of the story happen off-screen.

The fact that the avoided having chest high walls and a cover bottom is the only concession made to modern game design on display. This small grace helped it feel at least a bit like 40k and not like the Gears of War cover shooter it felt like most of the time. You still get your fill of invisible walls blocking your every movement while the game is busy acting out its budget Hollywood movie that you get in the way with your desire to play it. Most of the areas could as well be wrapped up in yellow and black â€œSTORYLINE â€?DO NOT CROSSâ€?tape.

Now take your Medal of Honor and leave, Doorfighter of Ultramar.

---

Oh wait, we also shipped with Multiplayer! As all game executives of the 00'ths have taught us: Every shooter needs a multiplayer!

Multiplayer during the campaign seamlessly replaces one of your AI companions with a player. A neat system that, apart from some net code issues leading to desync and teleporting, works most of the time. Post campaign PvE content then is replaying 6 pieces sliced from campaign maps over and over again to gain XP to level up each of the 6 classes. All in all, a very simplified version of coop games like Warhammer 40k: Darktide, Deep Rock Galactic or Helldivers. While it feels thrown in to justify the horrendously overpriced experience, it does allow for a more combat focused experience with fewer story exposition and waiting segments, which is welcome.

Posted: September 26
What is your Duty?
To serve the Emperor's Will.
What is the Emperor's Will?
That we fight and die.
What is Death?
It is our Duty.

Where there is uncertainty, I shall bring light.
Where there is doubt, I shall sow faith.
Where there is shame, I shall point atonement.
Where there is rage, I shall show its course.
My word in the soul shall be as my bolter in the field.

Without the Dark, there can be no Light,
We have purpose
Without the Lie, there can be no Truth,
We have purpose
Without the War, there can be no Victory,
We have purpose
Without the Death, there can be no sacrifice,
We have purpose
Without the Hope there can be no Future,
We have purpose
Without the Loyalty there can be no one chapter,
We have purpose
Without the Emperor, there is nothing,...
And we would have no purpose

Te obliga a quedarte con los mismos jugadores en lugar de buscar una nueva partida. Es ridÃ­culo. Todo es un caos, no puedes hacer nada, y para colmo, no hay ni un botÃ³n de reporte. Me encontrÃ© con un jugador que me mataba de un solo golpe, y el sistema me metiÃ³ en la misma sala con Ã©l Â¡dos veces seguidas! Inaceptable.

La historia merece un 9/10, pero el PvP se lleva un miserable 6/10. Necesita una mejora urgente, y ya ni hablemos del lobby, que es tan bÃ¡sico que duele. El PvP tiene potencial, pero ahora mismo estÃ¡ muy lejos de ser bueno. 100% recomendado.

Posted: September 23
It's a simple but quite fun game. No agenda pushing, no stupid identity politics. Just plain good old stay strong together and slay the aliens. Learn the pace of combat, choose the right weapons, play as a team, gather profit. The Emperor protects.

Posted: September 23
Writing this as I've finished all the achievements in the game.

Campaign is short but sweet, operations mode needs more maps, though it does offer endless replay-ability. PVP is fun, though some classes are better than others and there's just 3 maps to rotate out of, but overall,the game at launch is solid, with more promising content to come like horde mode, maps in both operations mode, and PVP, and hopefully more classes.

Terminids are hella fun to fight against however Chaos need a bit of rework; â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ the ranged weapons of Chaos Marines and the shielded Zhangors are tanky AF.

If you played this game and don't enjoy it, you're either playing on easy mode or you haven't mastered the flow of combat yet.

Other than the occasional network issues and crashes, this game is solid, and well worth the price I paid at launch. 10/10 would parry and gun strike for the Emperor again.

Posted: September 23
the campaign is making the pricetag look reasonable, even with the glitches/connection issues, this was still one of the coolest experiences i've had playing with two friends, pve is replayable, maps will get stale, but the gameplay is solid enough that i want to comeback and play a few runs

the game will be updated to include more content, seeing as devs gave us a roadmap

could be goty ?

and yeah, it's a different experience to play alone, and not in the good way, get two friends to buy the game along with you, preferably try to get a walking 40k lore library, makes the walkthrough that much better if someone can explain most of the things that you'll be experiencing throughout the campaign (if you know nothing about the universe, ofc)

Posted: September 21
40K Space marine 2.

So long have i waited for it's arrival and it was everything i wanted and so much much more. Waiting on a day to day, week to week and even HOUR TO HOUR basis for the game to come out after first preordering the game by saving up some allowance, the campaign felt cathartic and divine.
Nothing short of phenomenal for me who has been engrossed in this universe for the last 14-15 years of my damn life.

Every tidbit of detail, voice acting, set pieces and generally the entire game itself is crafted with love and care from people who understand the setting to it's core and do not care about anything else.

I wish young me could see this game and go "â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™?that's the future..."
So yea, you should play it.

Posted: September 21
Codex Approved
Campaign: Well paced plot is easy to digest and has a solid ending. Final boss fight is awesome with lots cool moment throughout.
Operations PVE: Lots to grind for and feels fairly challenging for progression; was hoping their be more than 6 ops, but they have promised more for free with each season.
Eternal War PVP: This mode unfortunately feel like it got done last minute. The game modes there are fine, but there's only 3 maps with spawns being terribly setup and classes definitely having balancing issues. More maps and mode have been promised, but balancing will come with time.
Customisation: There is tons to unlock for each class with plenty of colours and emblems to make whatever marine you can think of. That's at least for the loyalist astrates. The traitor astrates however suffer from same thing as pvp part of the game, probably cause they were done last minute as well. The armour is locked to a set class with only colours and emblem being changeable.

Overall an upgrade to everything in the previous game beside the pvp aspect at the moment. With plenty more content coming down the pipeline I'm sure it can only improve.
I give 9/10 nurglings.

As of November 2024, game still doing awesome and new content is great!

column4:
Posted: September 20
It's time to write a review. The main problems of this game:
1) Connection - constant connection errors in the "eternal war" mode, in particular problem 140, when you have to re-enter the game several times before all the stars align in the sky and you are allowed into the match, instead of being offered to go to the main menu once again . After which, by the way, nothing will change, you will still have to restart the game, and so on several times.
2) Chaos marine customization. We have a fairly rich customization for Loyalists and such a poor one for Chaos marine. Why are Chaos marine each class tied to a specific legion??? Why are there so few armor parts for them??? There are no my favorite "thousand sons" (Although they were in the main campaign of the game. Is it so difficult to integrate ready-made skins into pvp mode???). In general, Chaos marines are represented by a small number of legions, but where are the individual warbands, which are so numerous in the Warhammer 40k universe??? Here's another thing: Have you ever seen Berserker Khorne without a chain axe??? - and here you will see.
3) Class system. I will not say that some classes are completely unplayable, or become more or less playable only after opening some items. I have a completely different question here: Why does a game like "Total Tournament" or "Quake Arena" have a class system at all??? And the classes themselves do not inspire confidence: if the "Night Lords" still look in place, then Khorne berserkers in the form of a non-assault class are nonsense. Let me remind you that Saber "presses so much on lore in its communications with the community", for example, they have already answered the question: "why is each legion of chaos tied to a specific class?" - because it is according to the lore, and right then we see the berserker Khorne, who is clearly out of place. If you follow the class system, you will simply have to enter 100,500 thousand classes for each type of space marines, and then you will have to make 100,500 patches to balance this whole thing. I think it's easier to introduce a system of factions (legions), for example, you choose a legion to which specific types of space marines are available, and that's it. By the way, does anyone know why class experience in pvp mode??? (so I have classes that are developed to level 5, but how do they differ from the same class of level 1???)
4) I think it is no longer a secret for anyone that in the future it is a game service. Please remind me of the fate of most such "new generation" games))) I understand that all developers want to put their games on the "monetization rails" as soon as possible. I think at the stage of loot boxes with a small chance of dropping rare items, it will be possible to put the game on the "Steam shelf" and never come back here. I pre-ordered the max edition because I believed in this game, but if at some point I'm offered to buy skins and loot boxes in a AAA-game that's actually being sold instead of being offered for free, that would be a "slap in the face".

P.S I am giving a negative rating just to draw attention to the problems. The game is actually pretty good and has a lot of potential.

FOR THE EMPEROR!

Posted: September 20
As a 10 year veteran of the prequel. Space Marine 2 delivers on multiple areas. I greatly enjoyed the redemption arc this time around for Captain Titus. I never thought I would find out what happened to him after Graia. As of now weâ€™re little light on content and few minor issues, but the potential this game has can be endless. Looking forward to see what the Devs bring in the future.

Posted: September 19
Gioco indubbiamente divertente e dalla lore importante, ma per la cifra che chiedono il gioco ha problemi di crash specie in multiplayer, le operation che non sono altro che delle missioni alla vermintide, pensavo almeno fossero dungeon generati proceduralmente invece per crescere di livello bisogna ripetere le stesse missioni in continuazione, non si possono startare tramite lobby privata scegliendo magari di andare con i bot ma bisogna per forza aspettare che qualcuno si unisca in gruppo sono stato anche 20min prima di startare una missione, dulcis in fundus non e' detto che riusciate a pinnare la vostra classe perche' ad ogni inizio operation bisogna selezionarla da zero, ora ditemi voi se e' sensato nel 2024 sta roba, per startare una partita si devono attendere gli allineamenti astrali corretti. Cari sviluppatori volete fino a 90 bombe per il gioco allora dovete iniziare a rilascare giochi che abbiano gia' un senso all'uscita al momento di giocabile c'e' solo la campagna base che dura 10 ore. Consiglio vivamente di tenere l'hype ormai i giochi escono ma in realta' sono pronti dopo almeno 1 anno e io mi sono veramente rotto da fare da beta tester a pagamento.

Piccolo aggiornamento sulla progression:
che dire oltre al fatto che il match making non tiene conto della classe scelta dall'inizio ma bisogna ripinnare la classe ogni nuovo start di missione, volevo parlare di exp presa in gioco, exp lockata da step e token, e' impossibile allo stato attuale preparare il pg alle operation di livello superiore in quanto i materiali e denaro necessari a sbloccare le armi rare e poi leggenderie si prendono solo ed esclusivamente se si portano a termine le op. a livello elevato, calcolando i vari crash in gioco, calcolando che ci sono party dove buttano fuori l'indesiderato poco prima di finire la missione, calcolando la difficolta' dei nemici, al momento la progression e' totalmente da riguardare. Per quanto mi riguarda i token sono da togliere e le armi e armature si dovrebbero sbloccare semplicemente livellando il pg.

Posted: September 18
good

Posted: September 18
Space Marine 2 is an instant classic. It harkens back to the days when games were simple but fun. The campaign, while short, is a breath of fresh air when it comes to story-lines. The voice acting is perfect. It has one of the best representations of the WH40K world and most importantly, the Space Marines and the Imperium of Man. The storyline is simple but executed perfectly. The characters are simple as well, stoic, stalwart Marines who will risk death for their fellow brothers and their mission, and that's ok.

The devs and Saber should be proud of SM2. It's a return to classic gaming and what makes gaming fun. There's no hidden agendas, narratives or overt political messages shoved down our throats. There's no overly complicated characters with a plethora of problems pouring their hearts out and whining incessantly about how the world is against them. It's a simple storyline about brotherhood, duty, loyalty and just your basic good vs. evil. So refreshing.

Buy it. It's worth it. The campaign is gloriously fun and gets your blood pumping with the amazing cinematics. The multiplayer is addictive and isn't overly grindy. You truly feel more powerful as you level up. I look forward to new missions, enemies and PvP modes.

Posted: September 18
Personally I do enjoy this game and while this game certainly does have its ups and downs, I am not here to praise or criticize this game. I am here to offer a phenomenal 4 Cheese Ravioli recipe!

Here are the ingredients you will need!

Ravioli Dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 pinch salt, 1 teaspoon olive oil, 2 eggs, 1 1/2 tablespoons water.

Ravioli Filling: 1 (8 ounce) container ricotta cheese, 1 (4 ounce) package cream cheese, softened, 1/2 cup shredded mozzarella cheese, 1/2 cup provolone cheese, shredded, 1 egg, 1 1/2 teaspoons dried parsley.

Pesto-Alfredo Cream Sauce: 2 tablespoons olive oil, 2 cloves garlic, crushed, 3 tablespoons prepared basil pesto sauce, 2 cups heavy cream, 1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese, 1 (24 ounce) jar marinara sauce.


1. Mound the flour and salt together on a work surface and form a well. Beat the teaspoon of olive oil, 2 eggs, and water in a bowl. Pour half the egg mixture into the well. Begin mixing the egg with the flour with one hand; use your other hand to keep the flour mound steady. Add the remaining egg mixture and knead to form a dough.

2. Knead the dough until smooth, 8 to 10 minutes; add more flour if the dough is too sticky. Form the dough into a ball and wrap tightly with plastic. Refrigerate for 1 hour.

3. While the dough is resting, prepare the ravioli filling. Combine the ricotta cheese, cream cheese, mozzarella cheese, provolone cheese, egg, and parsley and mix well. Set the filling aside.

4. Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add the crushed garlic and pesto sauce and cook for one minute. Pour in the heavy cream, raise the heat to high, and bring the sauce to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 5 minutes. Add the Parmesan cheese and stir until the cheese melts. Remove the pan from the heat and keep warm.

5. Meanwhile, in a separate saucepan, warm the marinara sauce over medium-low heat.

6. Preheat an oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Beat the egg with the tablespoon of water to make the egg wash.

7. Roll out the pasta dough into thin sheets no thicker than a nickel. To assemble the ravioli, brush the egg wash over a sheet of pasta. Drop the filling mixture on the dough by teaspoonfuls about one inch apart. Cover the filling with the top sheet of pasta, pressing out the air from around each portion of filling. Press firmly around the filling to seal. Cut into individual ravioli with a knife or pizza cutter. Seal the edges.

8. Fill a large pot with lightly salted water and bring to a rolling boil over high heat. Stir in the ravioli, and return to a boil. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, until the ravioli float to the top and the filling is hot, 4 to 8 minutes. Drain well.

9. Grease a baking sheet. Place the cooked ravioli on the sheet pan and bake in the preheated oven until brown, about 4 minutes.

10. To serve the ravioli, divide them among four warmed serving bowls. Drizzle the marinara sauce over the ravioli and then top with the cream sauce.

Posted: September 16
My experience for me the battlefields of Avarax and analysis of the Battle reports collude to me that the fight against the Xenos scum is glorys and great fun Brother.

Pros:
The Game looks Butyfull same whit the gore.
The Story is around 10h long if you not try to run trought it .
The Wargear is quite large and all weapons feel unique.
Coop and Pvp are great wille still having a few server problem.

Con:
You get stuck in Loading screens often.
(Will probely be fixed soon)

Conclusion:
If you are loyal to the god Emporer you should join the fight against the Xenos scum and claim the Honor of the Abomunations you will slauhter.
You will not regret it 9,5/10

Brothers! The CRUSADE is waiting for you!

Posted: September 16
Imagina que Gears Of War y World War Z hubieran tenido un hijo, un hijo al que le han inyectado esteroides en vena y lo han dotado de caracterÃ­sticas como un combate brutal y visceral o un gunplay de los mejores que hemos tenido en lo que va de aÃ±o.

Pues creo que esta es una de las descripciones que mÃ¡s se acerca a lo que es el concepto de Space Marine 2.

Un juego bastante redondo, con una buena campaÃ±a que se puede jugar en cooperativo (lo cual es un plus) aunque es verdad que la historia a partir de la mitad flojea un poco, no quiero entrar en spoilers pero el cambio de facciÃ³n enemiga a mitad de juego parece que estÃ¡ un poco metido con calzador.

Un modo operaciones que estÃ¡ bastante bien y te anima bastante a jugarlo por que:

Primero: son misiones complementarias a las de la campaÃ±a, en los mismos entornos pero con otros lugares, soldados y objetivos. Como si de misiones secundarias se tratara pero orientadas al juego en equipo.

Segundo: tiene un sistema de clases y de progresiÃ³n bastante adictivo, donde insta a jugar para desbloquear mejoras de personaje, mejoras de arma y aspectos de ambos, ya que se consiguen puntos para hacer progreso en las herÃ¡ldicas o comprar nuevas habilidades de las clases con subidas de nivel.

Tercero: Son rejugables en cierta medida gracias a que tienen un poco de aleatoriedad como pasa en Warhammer 40.000 Darktide, con spawns random de oleadas, minibosses y cambios de objetos, RNG de items etc.

En cuanto al multijugador yo lo he encontrado bastante decepcionante por diversas razones.

La primera de todas es que son Arenas, que te da la sensaciÃ³n de jugar una mezcla rara entre un "Gears" multiplayer y un hero shooter por el tema de las habilidades de las clases.

Los mapas son pequeÃ±os, algo laberÃ­nticos y cerrados, a mÃ­ en lo personal me recuerdan mucho mÃ¡s a estar jugando a Quake/DooM arena que a otra cosa y la verdad es que es una formula que no me termina de convencer en un juego donde se juega en 3a persona y en el que los personajes creo que no son los idÃ³neos para este tipo de mapas, creo que hubiera sido un acierto mucho mÃ¡s grande el hacerlo un multijugador mÃ¡s "tradicional" o con un concepto algo mÃ¡s a lo titanfall, con PvPvE que tenga marines como jugadores y soldados normales controlados por IA, al menos yo creo que hubiera sido una experiencia mucho mÃ¡s disfrutable.

Al menos me da la sensaciÃ³n de que el juego no tiene SBMM y es algo de agradecer, el ping es bastante parejo asÃ­ que me da la sensaciÃ³n de que el juego busca por conexiÃ³n (eso si, el sistema de emparejamiento, no balancea ni aunque sea solamente un poco, en serio, de 10 partidas no he podido ganar ni una, no es normal la cantidad de pedazo de mancos que te tocan en un equipo, que yo no soy ningÃºn pro, pero consigo quedar con proporciones de 1.0-1.2 cuando tengo compaÃ±eros que tienen 0.1 es decir matar 1 y morir 8-9 veces)

En cuanto a nivel tÃ©cnico es bastante sublime, tiene un motor grÃ¡fico propietario de Saber Interactive que ya hemos visto en World War Z que tiene un rendimiento y un desempeÃ±o como pocos, en serio, pocos motores pueden mover tanto enemigo con tanto lujo de detalle y viendose tan bien con un rendimiento tan fluido (y me muero de ganas de que portee a Vulkan como en WWZ que te da sin problemas para jugar en ultra a 180fps seguro)

El sistema de combate cuerpo a cuerpo es muy bueno, con los combos y las esquivas, contraataques etc. El de combate a distancia ya si es algo mÃ¡s normalito y no tiene nada destacable o mencionable frente a cualquier otro shooter, no innova en nada a diferencia del CaC.

Igualmente es un juego bastante redondo, ya digo que tiene algunas carencias en mi opiniÃ³n, cosas que creo que le faltan (que imagino que se irÃ¡n aÃ±adiendo con el tiempo) como algunas armas o facciones ya que la selecciÃ³n de armas es muy pobre y todas se sienten muy parecidas salvo 2 o 3 y JODER DONDE ESTÃN LAS ESCOPETAS, en serio, no se si es que nadie las ha echado en falta o que, pero por si os habÃ©is dado cuenta no hay escopetas (y las hay en el elenco de armas del imperio) ya no hablo de que metan las porras o hachas de energÃ­a (que no estarÃ­a mal ya que el juego solo tiene 3 melÃ©s) pero es que me hace gracia que tienes como 7 rifles bÃ³lter que son el mismo arma con modos de fuego diferentes, 3 pistolas, 2 sniper y 2 armas de energÃ­a.... lo cual me parece un repertorio un poco pobre la verdad.

Otra cosa mala para mi es el multijugador, el de PVP, en serio, me parece lo peor que tiene el juego con diferencia, eso de que sean arenas pequeÃ±as en vez de campos de batalla con multitudes de enemigos que es lo que representa al universo, me parece un FAIL de manual (en mi humilde opiniÃ³n) por que si algo caracteriza al universo de WH40K es lo masivo de sus guerras y sus ejÃ©rcitos, y para mi eso no se ve representado en un mapa canijo en el que se juega un 6vs6 o un 8vs8 etc.

Si te gustan los juegos de Hordas y la ambientaciÃ³n de WH40K adelante, es un muy buen juego, me atrevo a decir que una de las mejores entregas que hemos visto y vamos a ver este 2024, si os gusta el universo, otra joya que veo indispensable es WH40K Darktide donde vais a ver en 1a persona el lado de un soldado en vez del de un marine espacial, ademÃ¡s de que se complementa muy bien con Space Marine 2 por que el juego se desarrolla en otros entornos y contra otras facciones como la plaga de Nurgle.

No soy muy de poner notas a un juego y menos de lanzamiento cuando tiene todo el contenido post-lanzamiento por delante pero le darÃ­a un 7,5-8/10 a Space Marine 2 y no mÃ¡s por que para mi falla bastante en el Multijugador PVP, de verdad que me parece el peor modo del juego y lo que mÃ¡s trabajo necesita para estar a la altura del resto del juego, es un modo bastante olvidable que no aporta nada al nÃºcleo del juego. No innova en nada, y ni siquiera dirÃ­a que es divertido, lo veo anticuado y fuera de esta Ã©poca como concepto y como modo de juego, en cuanto al resto del tÃ­tulo 10/10.

Das Spiel ist gut!



- Die Grafik ist Stimmig bis sehr gut.
- Das Movement ist naja.. man kann es aber spielen (Tastenbelegung ist Ã¤nderbar).
- Die Abwechslung kommt gerade zur rechten Zeit, damit man nicht gelangweilt wird.
- Mit guter Hardware lÃ¤uft das Spiel sehr gut! (Mein RIG ist in meinem Profil)

Es kommt trotzdem ein ABER:

ABER ich bin kein Fan dieses Franchises und habe mir so gut wie nichts vorher angesehen, durchgelesen oder angehÃ¶rt und muss einfach, nachdem ich die Story mit einem Kollegen im Koop durchgespielt habe zum Schluss kommen:
FÃ¼r jemanden der sich im Warhammer 40k Universum kaum bis gar nicht auskennt, bleibt am Ende bis auf ein gutes Action-Spiel gar nichts Ã¼brig.

Die Story wird man nicht verstehen, bei den Charakteren weiÃŸ man nicht wer wer ist oder welcher Rang jetzt was ist und so weiter und so weiter. Es bleibt einem einfach nur Ballern Ballern Ballern.

Und ich bin der festen Meinung, das ist auch jedes Mal der Genickbruch dieses eigentlich sehr interessanten Universums. Es reicht in meinen Augen einfach nicht aus, wenn man ab und zu mal Namen nennt, die einem vielleicht gar nichts sagen, dann fÃ¼r sich stehen und dann nicht weiter thematisiert werden.
Ich habe nach Teil 2 erst einmal den ersten Teil gespielt um zu gucken, ob ich einen WOW oder AHA Effekt bekomme, aber es ist in Teil 1 ja noch schlimmer mit den fÃ¼r mich nichts aussagenden EinwÃ¼rfen von Namen.

Wenn ich eine Lore oder ein Universum erst "Studieren" muss um eine Story eines einzelnen Spiels zu verstehen, dann ist die verdammt noch mal nicht gut oder nicht gut rÃ¼bergebracht.
Dann ist es einzig und alleine Fanservice und ob das fÃ¼r die breite Masse ausreicht, da habe ich meine Zweifel.

Trotzdem hatte und wer ich noch SpaÃŸ an diesem Spiel haben, so das eine Empfehlung trotz fÃ¼r mich nicht existierender Story noch gerade so gegeben ist.

Posted: September 15
Battle Report: Space Marines 2

From the Desk of Brother-Sergeant Gabriel, 3rd Company, Ultramarines Chapter

Mission Log: 15 Hours In, Campaign Complete

Hail, Brothers and Sisters of the Imperium,

The long-awaited call to arms has been answered. Space Marines 2 has descended upon us like a righteous storm, and after dedicating a solid 15 hours to its campaign and accessories, it is time to deliver our verdict.

Space Marines 2 has risen to meet the high expectations set by its predecessor and then some. The narrative, steeped in the grimdark lore of the 40K universe, unfolds with the gravitas expected of our sacred battlefields. Each mission is a crucible of intensity, keeping the Emperorâ€™s light blazing as you face the myriad horrors that plague the galaxy. The campaign's storyline is robust, providing a compelling blend of heroism and tragedy that befits the grand saga of the Space Marines.

Combat is a symphony of visceral destruction, every engagement a testament to the might of the Adeptus Astartes. The bolterâ€™s roar and the chain sword's hum are rendered with such fidelity that it feels as though youâ€™re wielding these sacred relics yourself. The enemies are varied and formidable, challenging even the most seasoned warriors among us. The improved AI ensures that no battle is ever truly predictable, demanding tactical acumen and reflexes as sharp as a power sword.

Graphically, the game captures the dark majesty of the 40K universe with hauntingly beautiful environments and detailed character models. The ambiance is as oppressive as a Space Hulk, with every setting dripping in the atmosphere of an Imperium on the brink.

In terms of gameplay, the enhancements to combat mechanics and the new abilities granted to our esteemed warriors are noteworthy. The balance between raw power and strategic depth has been finely tuned, allowing us to crush the xenos and heretics with righteous fury.

However, the path of the righteous is not without its trials. There are moments when the mission design feels somewhat formulaic, and a few technical hiccups mar the otherwise flawless execution of this grand endeavor. Yet, these are but minor blemishes on an otherwise gleaming armor of excellence.

In conclusion, Space Marines 2 stands as a proud addition to the legacy of the Warhammer 40K series. It honors our tradition of battle while forging a new path with unwavering zeal. For those who walk the line of the Emperorâ€™s light, this is a battle worth engaging in.

In the Emperor's Name,

Posted: September 14
Very fun gameplay but not worth the $60 they are charging

The campaign takes about 6 to 7 hours to beat which is alright but you don't make any progress towards your classes or weapons in it which is REALLY dumb, the main thing people are going to be doing is trying to is level up their classes to be able unlock armor to make your character look good. The Operations mode is the only mode where you can grind for class levels but sadly there are only 6 missions which they expect you to grind over and over again but in 4 difficulties for 6 classes and 25 levels each. The PvP has it's own leveling system for some reason instead of just going off the operations levels and making it another source of leveling classes. Other than that it's an unbalanced pvp mode with only 3 modes and 3 maps that seems to be added as an after thought.

Could of been GOTY worthy cause of the PvE gameplay if it wasn't for the lack of content, poor performance, bugs, glitches and $60 price tag. I am glad I only paid $49 for this game but even then I feel as if it should have been $30 for the content it has right now.

Some things I like about this is no battlepass and no in game shop. Plus all the content they plan to add is going to be free, so eventually it will have enough content to warrant the $60 price tag.

Buy it during a sale!

Posted: September 14
Space Marine 2 is a good example of what we've lost due to games as a service and predatory monetization schemes, with videogames whose sole purpose of development is to serve as a cosmetics and skins virtual store.
Saber has transported me back to the first decade of the 2000s when video games were just art and pure entertainment. For sure this is not a perfect game, but it is certainly a great one. A solid campaign, cooperative mode and a multiplayer mode, which is simple, but very fun and entertaining, with a progression system and lots of rewards to unlock for free. Just like in the good ol' days.
How good it feels to be able to play a video game with no developer-generated fomo to encourage battle passes sales, with a clear roadmap before release, no microtransactions and no in-game store.
Space Marine 2 is visually amazing with stunning graphics, the combat system is smooth and action packed with a blood and gore feast. I'm playing it on a 3080 with no problems or bugs so far, but I think they can optimize the game even more for my fellow brothers who don't own a beefy GPU.
The Emperor has delivered. The Emperor will provide. For the Emperor!

Posted: September 13
In summary, a successful game. The worlds are beautifully designed and the story is very well done (what has been released so far).

However, the endgame is very one-sided and currently played through quickly. You now only play to tune your skins a little. Stats/values on the upgrades would have been something else that would have been motivating.

I can currently recommend the game as there is still a lot to be released, but after about 20 hours you have to wait until the new content arrives.

column5:
Posted: September 12
After reading the negative reviews and assessing their statements, I have decided I should write a review.
One of the biggest complaints I saw was people complaining that the 2 highest difficulties of the campaign "Require" Co-Op. Whether it was because missions were hard, the AI was incompetent, or enemies took too many bullets to kill, requiring you to use a "Janky" melee system. I beat the campaign on the highest difficulty solo; one of my friends beat the campaign solo on that difficulty as well. News flash. A co-op game is usually balanced around playing co-op with either friends or other people.
The second complaint I saw was the game being "stiff" or "unresponsive" and the combat being janky. The combat is supposed to feel slow. Poorly timed dodges and parries are punished. Spamming attacks are supposed to be unrewarding at best and punished at worst. People kept mentioning that they can't cancel a dodge. I didn't even know that was a normal feature in games. Usually you press the button, action happens, and then you resume. Sometimes games will let you "Cancel" something if it's a long action like a reload or mantling a ledge.
PVP isn't super unbalanced. There are some tweaks that need to be made, but on the whole it's enjoyable as long as your teammates realize this isn't a normal shooter. It's more akin to CS or Valorant. You want to play with your team and play Objectives. A solo player can pop off, but more often than not, a solo player gets caught out and killed quickly.
To the people who are saying this is another "short life" game because it has low re-playability. Unlike a lot of other games that are trying to be in this space, it has a road map. We know what's coming and when to expect it. Thats more than I can say for a lot of games like this.

To wrap it all in a nice bow. Remember, other games exist. Go play them.

Posted: September 12
I've played a couple other Warhammer games before but this one so far is my favorite. There are a couple things I'm not a fan of like the defense objective in one of the early missions and managing ammo especially in certain encounters but overall It's a really fun game. Looking forward to seeing what they add to it in the future.

Posted: September 12
Great story and the multiplayer is fun and challenging! Haven't tried PVP but from what i can tell the ttk is in a nice spot and can add some more life to the game. If the Devs can keep a steady stream of content then i can see this game doing really well. If not, for those who seek a more PVE style of game play, they might burn out pretty quick due to the repetitious nature of the multiplayer operations, even though the enemies are procedural (kinda), the mission objectives can get a little stale. However, the progression system and different classes help for those who seek to grind like i do, i can see myself easily putting 100+ hours chasing those levels and gear. Lastly, the campaign took me about 8 hours on normal and that's with exploring every nook for hidden data pads on normal but by the end you'll be shouting "FOR THE EMPEROR!"

Posted: September 11
TLDR: Game is very good, GOTY for me.

As an enjoyer of 40k its nice to be eating good again.

This is a masterpiece, I haven't played a game that has made me this happy in a long time. The gameplay, the lore, the graphics, all of it sings of love and care. This game has so many little details that have made me and my friends stop and appreciated them (not mentioning which in order to avoid spoiling).

The gameplay is visceral and responsive, simple to pick up but with some dept to it.
The lore, according to my more learned friends as I am but a novice in the 40k ways, is very good, and they took great care with some details.
And the graphics are beautiful, the contrast between the amazing visceral displays in combat and the beautiful but war thorn landscape around is amazing.

This topped off with non-predatory monetisation, only cosmetics can be bought, and even then there are plenty to earn in game, the future updates are free and will bring so many wonderful things is such a breath of fresh air.

I know some people had a couple of bugs, and I too experienced some, nothing game breaking, but some crashes and some goofy physics in cutscenes. I am hoping today's patch addressed that for new players.

Courage and Honour!

"In the grim darkness of the far future, there is only war"

From the moment you step into your power armor, youâ€™re no longer just a human, youâ€™re a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™?walking cathedral of destruction, blessed by the Emperorâ€™s divine will. Xenos? Heretics? Chaos-worshipping filth? Theyâ€™re not your enemies, theyâ€™re your next target practice. Reload, deliver, and repeat until the galaxy is cleansed.

The Combat
Itâ€™s pure, undiluted rage made flesh. You donâ€™t just kill your enemies, you annihilate them with every pull of the trigger, as if the Emperor himself is screaming â€œPurge harder!â€?in your ears!

It's simple, if itâ€™s not human, it dies. You donâ€™t need context or a reason; theyâ€™re xenos, they exist, thatâ€™s enough to condemn them. You are the Emperorâ€™s fist, and the galaxy is your punching bag.











9/10 â€?Would obliterate xenos and heretics again while screaming â€˜FOR THE EMPEROR!â€?,en

Ich habe die Kampagne auf der hÃ¶chsten Schwierigkeit durchgespielt und aktuell zwei Charaktere â€?einen Verteidiger und einen ZerstÃ¶rer â€?auf Level 25.

Die Kampagne ist hervorragend umgesetzt und fÃ¤ngt die dÃ¼stere, epische AtmosphÃ¤re von Warhammer perfekt ein. Man fÃ¼hlt sich wirklich wie ein Teil dieses riesigen Universums â€?einfach fantastisch. Auch die Koop-Missionen sind sehr gelungen und machen eine Menge SpaÃŸ, allerdings sind die Chaos-Missionen noch etwas unausgewogen.

Der PvP-Modus ist unterhaltsam, aber es gibt noch Luft nach oben. Mit nur drei Spielmodi und etwa fÃ¼nf Maps ist das Angebot noch recht begrenzt. Zudem fehlt es den Chaos Marines an Anpassungsoptionen, was dem PvP etwas an Tiefe nimmt. Hier sehe ich die grÃ¶ÃŸte SchwÃ¤che des Spiels.

Das Spiel lÃ¤uft auÃŸerdem extrem stabil. In meiner gesamten Spielzeit hatte ich nur einen einzigen Bug, aber keinen Absturz oder sonstige Probleme â€?es ist wirklich sehr gut optimiert.

An alle, die sich beschweren, dass es keine Pronomen, Frauen, LGBTQ+ oder andere ReprÃ¤sentationen gibt: Im echten Leben kÃ¶nnt ihr all das gerne so ausleben, wie ihr wollt, aber in Warhammer geht es nur um Krieg! Lasst das Universum so, wie es seit den 90ern ist. Wenn es euch nicht passt, sucht euch bitte etwas anderes und lasst uns unser Warhammer so lieben, wie es ist: dÃ¼ster und gnadenlos. DARK and GRIM.

Trotz kleinerer MÃ¤ngel ist Warhammer Space Marine 2 ein groÃŸartiges Spiel, das ich jedem Fan des Universums oder Action-Gamern wÃ¤rmstens empfehlen kann.

Posted: September 10
The style of the game is on point with satisfying gameplay, but it has some GLARING issues. I'd recommend it, but I hope it gets some polish soon!

Pros:
Style: The feel of the 40k universe is really hit on the head. This alone has probably gotten me through the game. I just really adore it.
Audio: Crunchy sound design is very satisfying.
Weapons: The gear you use feels pretty good, the design is limited, but it's loyal to the universe.
Gameplay: Fairly rhythmic fighting with parries, counters & dodges.
Big enemies: Boss fights can be tough ( Angel of Death difficulty ), but typically manageable ( caveat below ).
Story: The story is a bit shallow, but good enough.

Cons:
The most glaring issue is ally AI. It's horrendous, pathetically bad. This can make some boss fights an absolute slog when you're trying to balance yourself to proceed through the fight. It also destroys immersion seeing an Astartes knuckle f***ing himself in the corner while you're fighting for your life.
Hit boxes: The hit boxes are bad. You'll get hit at bizarre ranges & you'll often shoot invisible walls when attacking enemies. I've also been struck countless times through cover from ranged attacks.
Homing Melee Attacks: One the most annoying things in this game is enemies leaping at you ( not talking about parry counters ) & having them turn in the air or have them YA YEET themselves after you when you dodge.
Stun Lock: Though I understand it's a swarm hitting you & that's sort of the point, getting stun locked is just a poor choice. No one likes stun lock. No one likes losing control of their character. No one wants to have 2/3 of their health gone from 3 gaunts.

Edit:

Tacked on Feature: After finally playing the PvP I gotta' say it's pretty dog-sh*t. The fact that you have to re-level up just to use weapons is a very brain-dead decision. It's artificial play time that should not exist in a game where PvP feels like a tack-on to begin with. Being dumped into games where the majority of my team is > Level 10 & the opponents are < Level 20 is laughable. Less options, less-powerful gear ( in some aspects ) & less experience vs a team higher in all regards. Trashy.

Posted: September 10
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is nothing short of a triumph, seamlessly merging intense combat with a gripping narrative in a way that will captivate both long-time fans and newcomers alike. This latest installment in the Warhammer 40K universe sets a new standard for action-packed shooters with its impeccable blend of brutal melee combat, strategic gunplay, and stunning visuals. Saber Interactive really came through with this installment. It is a game that long time fans of Warhammer 40k truly have been asking for.

From the moment you step into the power armor of a Space Marine, the game impresses with its attention to detail. The graphics are absolutely breathtaking paired with a bombastic audio design, Space Marine 2 showcases the grimdark universe with a level of realism that immerses you completely. The environments are richly detailed, from the war-torn landscapes to the imposing architecture of the Imperiumâ€™s strongholds.

The combat is where Space Marine 2 truly shines. The gameplay feels both fluid and weighty, with a seamless transition between hand-to-hand combat and ranged weaponry. The abilities and upgrades add depth and variety, ensuring that each encounter remains fresh and exhilarating. The gameâ€™s AI is notably sharp, presenting a formidable challenge that keeps you on your toes without ever feeling unfair.

Narratively, the game excels in delivering a compelling story set against the backdrop of a galaxy in turmoil. The voice acting and script are top-notch, with a storyline that feels both epic and personal. The character development is rich, and the dialogue manages to balance gravitas with moments of dark humor, adding layers to the experience.

Multiplayer has a offering of diverse modes and a progression system that keeps the action engaging and competitive. Whether youâ€™re battling in co-op missions or competing in PvP, the multiplayer experience is both rewarding and addictive. Looking forward to see what Saber Interactive does with future content.

In summary, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a masterclass in combining thrilling gameplay with a deep, immersive world. Itâ€™s a must-play for fans of the franchise and a standout entry for those new to the universe. This game not only meets but exceeds expectations, proving itself as a benchmark in the genre. Prepare for a relentless, adrenaline-pumping adventure that you wonâ€™t soon forget.

Posted: September 10
-linear gameplay
-a melee combat game with guns
-wanabe souls game with the parry/dodge mechanic
-no character progression, no leveling, no gear
-no armor/gear except for default weapons and unlocked weapons from story
-combat is slow, why slow run and fast run? just do fast run as default
-guns do not feel good, low ammo, hard to find ammo at times
-melee base combat but no weapon skills just some clunky multi-hit combo
-generic melee weapons, generic guns
-not enough health kits, not enough ammo on some fights
-sucks playing solo, you get swarmed fast
-have to switch between gun mode and melee mode, this feels so bad. Gun mode locks you into zoomed-in 3rd person ADS
-can't tell if there's different classes, everyone looks the same
-dodge roll spam
-too many enemies with range abilities
-guns suck so you are forced into melee combat when you run out of ammo


Overall: A white guy, asian guy, and black guy walks into the jungle.....game sucks, Remnant 2 did it better

Posted: September 10
Space Marine 2 offers a great blend of PVE and PVP action, as well as a compelling story, once again featuring Demetrian Titus of the Ultramarines. If you're a fan of the Warhammer 40,000 IP, you're going to love it. If you're just getting into this IP, buckle up and enjoy! For the Emperor!

Posted: September 10
Space Marine 2 is a long-awaited, much-hoped-for sequel to the first Space Marine game. You play as <REDACTED> (jk it's freaking Titus like that wasn't obvious enough) who starts off using Primaris-styled equipment as a regular first-born marine. Hmm. Can't say that's particularly lore accurate, but whatever, it's Titus so that's cool. Unfortunately he's no Mark Strong this time, can't blame him after everything that happened. Be aware.

I tried playing the campaign missions on Angel of Death difficulty. This will color my breakdown below.

The 'nids are, as expected, annoying ass space bugs that swarm you faster than skaven do at a Warpstone rave party, and they're fairly dangerous. In fact, each of them individually might not seem like a problem but start throwing in 3 or so hormagaunts and you'll start having more stab wounds than a mugging victim in London. The termagaunts, those little annoying freaking shooty bugs, appear to not wield regular fleshborers, since the damn things flash green like miniature rapid-fire venom cannons. If you don't know what a venom cannon is, I'll explain it further down below in the Warrior section.

All of these swarm mechanics overwhelming you through sheer numbers is really pronounced. I started having to take engagements carefully and seriously right from the get-go. You can't regenerate any health from simple executions this time either, you need to have taken damage recently (a la Bloodborne) and this makes Titus not only feel like tissue paper, but unable to recover easily. You need to use the medical stims and those are far and few in between, so they definitely took the 'its too easy' critique about the first game too much to heart. Titus will find these enemies dangerous and annoying in equal measure as a result, so don't go thinking you can charge into the jaws of hell and not get tarpitted harder than Abbadon facing a 50 block of guardsmen backed up by a Commissar Lord. They are just as fearless as said guardsmen and unlike Abbadon, Titus can't â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out like 10 attacks in a single round of combat, so you better hope you're good at parrying.

Note that while parrying or dodging or attacking, you are more or less animation locked. You can't cancel easily, and this honestly makes you feel a lot more sluggish than Captain Titus, who is now obviously the best version of Titus there was. This means you have to thin their numbers at range, hopefully reducing the 'gaunt variants down to less than 3 by the time the Warrior rushes you down.

Let's talk about Warriors. Warriors are the big 'nids that have that annoying ass whip, that annoying ass paired boneswords, that really annoying ass devourer, or that annoying ass venom cannon (that long snout thing).
The Whip is not too bad in a 1 on 1, just make sure to either stay clear of it while wiping out the small forms or...dunno, charge in and beat it to death before it can get really annoying. When it does that lash combo attack, it's very hard to parry so you're better off just trying to keep your distance and shooting it down.
The twin boneswords is just tanky. That's it.
The devourer is basically a rapid-fire fleshborer, and the Warrior who uses it is the most irritating PoS you will ever encounter. It will constantly skate away to the backline to pepper you with clusters of projectiles and it adds up a lot of damage very fast. Snipe this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ as soon as possible. If you try to close in melee, it will sometimes unload every shot into you at point-blank range and you can die from this.
The last one, the venom cannon wielder, is the sniper variant. A venom cannon is like a biological railgun except instead of shooting a metal projectile it shoots this venomous acidic crystal that is superheated by the electrical discharge (yes, this is how it works in lore) and is launched at high speed to penetrate vehicles...or something. It didn't really work against real vehicles, but it definitely works against MEQ (shorthand for 'marine equivalent') like Titus. You will get a warning in the form of a sickly green laser tracking you and you can dodge the shot quite easily with good timing. The real problem is when one of them shows up and you are fighting a swarm or two and their Warrior melee cousins all at the same time, which is when things get nasty. Even then, its particular attacks are not hard to avoid, so either trust in your mobility or kill them off first, your choice.

There's more bug variants and their stupid tactics but I'm tired of talking about bugs so let's talk about weapons.

Gunplay and melee aren't mutually exclusive, it retains the general fluidity of the first game and you can swap between the two styles of combat very fast. Pistols are actually useful, they take their own slot and can help offset some disadvantages of your primary, while also serving as a way to perform kill shots on parried enemies.

Bolters. Holy Emperor the bolters. There are so many bolter variants, and some of them being very cross purposes with their actual function to the point it makes you wonder who needs this many variants. They are all lifted from the Primaris arsenal, and you get the whole freaking line of them (except Assault Bolters). Bolt carbines, heavy bolt pistols, auto bolt rifles, you name it they have it. In fact, I would argue that there are simply too many bolters. In the first game most of the same roles were replicated by unique weapons, such as the plasma gun, the lascannon, the vengeance launcher, and so on. Now you get...bolters.

Some of them are effective and some are not, but all of them are only average on Angel of Death difficulty so I didn't really find them to be that unique. What stood out were the non-bolter weapons, the Plasma Incinerator and the Melta Rifle.
The Plasma Incinerator is like a cross between the regular plasma gun and a very small plasma cannon, and it performs well enough in that role. It's plasma and it hurts.
The Melta Rifle is basically just like the melta gun from the first game. Tight AOE cone that does more damage the closer to the center of the aiming circle you get, huge shotgun blast that can melt anything.
There's some other stuff like the Las Fusil, which is basically just a lascannon if they scaled it down and in-game it's basically a Charge Rifle from Titanfall. It's still a good weapon, but they clearly learned their lesson from the first game where the lascannon's instant shot could utterly destroy an unfortunate enemy's face at close range.

Melee weapons unfortunately all feel a little samey. The chainsword is effective but it only swings in tight arcs and relies on a charge attack combo to stun enemies, which is extremely awkward compared to the first game where your stun/charge attack was another key altogether. This means it is very easy to start a chainsword combo then get hit for your trouble because you have no way of interrupting your enemy.
The power sword is a little more forgiving as it has actual stances that emphasize AOE or single target combat. It still has the issue of not being able to stagger big creatures reliably, or having a charge attack combo that matters, but it is reliable enough with its large sweeping attacks to actually outperform the chainsword on a regular basis.
The thunder hammer took a big hit from last game. It is just as sluggish and slow despite Titus' better augmentations, but is weaker. You can put a lot of hurt on enemies, but you have too many gaps open that leave you unable to defend yourself properly. Compare that to the first game, where the hammer's instant-kill damage and reliable stun combo can AOE wipe out hordes of daemons or whatever. It's very weak in this game.
The power fist staggers most enemies. Good enough.

So Is game gud? yes. Get. Play. Keel bug.

Posted: September 10
Glorious grim dark Warhammer 40k! This game really is a love letter for Warhammer 40k fans. By no means is it perfect, but compared to some of the other 40k and Warhammer Fantasy games, this game is amazing. So much attention to detail and love given to this game and setting. Often while playing I stop just to look around, which I do not do often. So much to take in!

Ignore GW and their nonsense on Warhammer+, this is where TRUE Warhammer is, grab your Bolters Brothers, we have many more abominations to kill!

Posted: September 10
Product refunded

IF YOU SUFFER FROM MOTION SICKNESS THIS MIGHT NOT BE YOUR GAME.
if you DO NOT suffer from motion sickness then this game is metal af. buy it lol.

the narrow fov with no adjustability is the only deal breaking issue i have with the game. i dont wanna give the game a bad review because the other aspects of the game are great, BUT its basically unplayable for me.
i can only play for about 2 hours on my desktop setup before i had stop because i was becoming physically ill.

However playing on my htpc setup with a 50â€?tv several feet away is tolerable.

in 2024, an fov slider is a basic QOL option for most people and for some (like me) is a legit accessibility option that makes the game playable.
not having an fov slider is like not having subtitles for the hearing impaired.

IF an fov slider is added i will update my review to positive cause the rest of the game is alot of fun

NOTE: im aware that there are fov fixes/mods but i shouldn't need to jump through hoops to enjoy the game.

Posted: September 10
Incredible game, 9/10 cannot recommend enough.

It would be a 10/10 Emperor mandated purchase but there were a few gamebreaking bugs that me and my friend encountered during our playthrough that made us have to restart several times.

The pvp is skill based and requires you to move as a unit like OG halo multiplayer and the movement feels a lot like gears of war minus the cover to cover aspect of moving in that game.

The Campaign immediately entered my top 5 best campaigns along with Halo and Last of Us. The final missions is pure unfiltered fan service and I couldn't get enough of it.

The Scenarios are also awesome and provide a good bit of replay-ability with the perks and cosmetic unlocks and each class feels powerful in their own right.

One of my personal favorite things in this game has to be NO MICRO-TRANSACTIONS!!!

All in all its an amazing game that I'm having a ton of fun with and i even have zero regrets when it comes to purchasing the early access either which is the first time I have done so in years.

Posted: September 10
I really hate to do this so early on, but out of my alleged 2 hours of "playtime", only 20-30 minutes has actually been in control of a Space Marine. I'm not joking when I say I've simply started scrolling through twitter and watching whole YouTube videos whilst waiting for things to load, and it also turns out that despite having downloaded the game for no less than 4 hours, I am SOMEHOW missing some "Epic Games Multiplayer Files". For some reason, loading into the Campaign requires connecting to a server, and basically every single cut-scene has either frozen itself partway through, has had such delayed audio that it's genuinely confusing as to who's saying what unless you have Subtitles on, or flat out just crashes the game. That half an hour I've actually been able to play the game was fun, I admit, but that simply does NOT excuse how everything outside of the gameplay seems to have been handled.

Oh, and on a separate note, a friend of mine from the UK wanted me to gift this for them when it released today and I couldn't due to "Regional Price differences". Turns out that people in the UK are paying what is effectively an extra $12 in USD for this game compared to Americans, so please do note that if you are from that region across the big pond.

Edit: Game seems to be running a lot better now, so now that I can physically play the video game I'm changing the review. Price difference still seems to be an issue, though, so make of it what you will.

In the Emperor's name, Space Marine 2 is a hymn to war, drenched in the blood of xenos heretics. Captain Titus leads his battle-brothers in a glorious purge, their bolters roaring like the thunder of Terra. The combat is as brutal and unyielding as the Imperium itself, though mission variety and accessibility are as scarce as an untainted world in the 41st Millennium. Yet, the gameâ€™s visual splendor and rousing voice work echo the divine light of the God-Emperor. A must for any true servant of humanity. FOR THE EMPEROR!!

Sehr gute Grafik, brutal, nicht zu einfach und nicht zu schwierig, gute customization, kaum Bugs und nichts was das Game breaken kÃ¶nnte, ein sich gut anfÃ¼hlendes Kampfsystem mit geilen Kontern und Finishern, viel frei zu spielen, bombastische Inszenierung, Performance ist selbst auf Ã¤lteren Systemen noch spielbar dank DLSS und auch Lossless Scaling(es ist auch ohne LS spielbar aber ich bin eine FPS-Ho3)

Contra:
kurze Story(6 Missionen die jeweils ca 1h lang sind), kein Widescreen-Support(Ã¤ndert sich bald schon), erstmal nur 6 PvE Missionen(wieder ca 45-1h lang und an sich gehÃ¶ren sie auch zur Story sollen aber dieses Jahr noch mehr kommen laut Roadmap), falls du auch ne Fps-Ho3 bist brauchst du Lossless Scaling(auÃŸer du hast ne 3070+), relativ repetetive ohne Hordemodus, Crossplay fÃ¼hrt noch zu langen Ladezeiten, Server sind noch nicht perfekt

Fazit: ne gute 7.5, wenn noch mehr Content kommt wahrscheinlich 8-9

Specs: rtx 2080, r5 7600
Ich nutze Losless Scaling und DLSS(QualitÃ¤t) um auf simulierten 150 fps zu spielen

Anmerkung: Ich schreibe diese Rezension aus der Sicht von Jemandem der kein Warhammer Fan ist/war. FÃ¼r Warhammer Fans ist das hier wahrscheinlich noch ein grÃ¶ÃŸeres Fest
