Posted: September 9
I have been hoping for a sequel for space marine for 11 years, I have been waiting for this to release for 2 years. Does it deliver? I will explain below, starting with the campaign, then the MP modes ending on the technical details and overall thoughts.

Campaign


Space Marine 2 puts you into the armour of a Space Marine 40.000 years into the future. A genetically engineered super soldier that is 3 metres tall, a space marine is almost indestructible, they are faster and stronger than any normal human and some of them can be hundreds of years old. They are wrapped in myth and legend and are skilled warriors beyond measure. They are a bulwark against terror in a universe that has known only war for centuries.

Humanity is fighting against horrors beyond their comprehension and while there are several factions of said horrors, the main one we're dealing with here, is a Tyranid Hive fleet.
Tyranids are a bug/lizard like faction that swarm the universe to consume biomass, they evolve at an incredibly fast rate and can counter almost any known weapon or biological agent known to mankind and speed is of the essence when dealing with them. A planet attacked by them never truly recovers and there are millions and millions gunning for you.

The story picks up quite some time after Space Marine 1, and you are Titus. While I won't go into much story detail. The tutorial and thus the introduction to Space Marine 2, immediately shows what stakes you're up against and sets the tone for the entire campaign.

The campaign is a great introduction to some of the scale that Warhammer 40K offers and its bleak hopeless setting, there is only war and it shows. The campaign is filled with gigantic set pieces, wild lush alien forests and jungles, gigantic cities with massive cathedrals or abandoned bunkers and dark secrets. Everywhere you see signs of the carnage that happens all around you and the grimdark setting that 40K invented really shines here.

Gameplay wise the game is reminiscent of Space Marine 1, just improved upon. combat is fast and diverse and the game expects you to switch tactics on the fly.

As a space marine you have a great arsenal of weapons to use, from the infamous Bolt weapons, massive assault weapons that fire a bolt, a massive rocket propelled round that embeds itself in the target and detonates, to melta guns, plasma guns, heavy bolters. But you also have several melee weapons, from the Chainsword, to the Thunderhammer. Why? because the combat in this games switches between thinning out hordes and hordes of enemies before they reach you and then turns into a hack and slash brawler fest.

The combat is incredibly dynamic and it keeps you on your toes especially on higher difficulties. Luckily you are not alone in this rigorous slaughter fest. Titus has two other space marines with him, which can either be controlled by your friends or the computer. While the bots lack some finesse and tend to focus on direct threats, they are a welcome addition. Just don't expect too much of them, they are bots. they beeline for you to get you up if you're down but not out and they can distract some enemies.

The campaign will take you around 10 to 12 hours to complete and my time with it was enjoyed very much, I had several "Holy sh!t" moments and I felt like a space marine, the story is all I hoped for after 13 years and I loved it.


The multiplayer is the other part of Space Marine 2. It can be separated in two parts: PVE and PVP.


PVE is one of the parts that shines here, during the campaign several squads often help Titus with secondary objectives, the PVE or Operations gives you control of these squads. You can run this with up to two of your friends or bots, but trust me, play with friends.

You have six classes with each of them having a distinct role, weapon set and main ability.
From the standard space marine with bolter and chainsword, to the bulwark with shield and sword to a stealthy sniper

Each class has weapon upgrades, perks for the weapons and the class itself and customisation to unlock.
Yes you can create your very own space marine or unlock several other space marine chapters and customise those and while the customisation needs some polish, it's incredibly varied.

There are currently six operations most of which coincide with the campaign, they can take 30 to 45 minutes to complete and on higher difficulties they require coordination, tactics and sharing of resources.

They often feel like mini raids and they are incredibly fun to do, however in contrast to games such as Darktide I wonder how fun these missions stay, they feel less like a horde shooter and more like a mini campaign, while enemy variety and objectives can switch around in an operation, I feel it might get repetitive. Yet they are like I said incredibly fun and I will probably keep coming back to them, just because of the gameplay loop.


The second MP mode is Eternal War, a 6v6 PVP mode with the same classes as the Operations mode, just different progression. There three modes, King of the Hill, Seize ground (several points to capture) and Annihilation (team death match) and as of writing 3 maps.

The gameplay in pvp is great, classes are diverse and while some balancing might be happening it is incredibly fun to play despite it's lack of maps and modes. I spend several hours playing this and the tactical aspect in it is really fun, it isn't just run and gun, you have to counter other classes, bullwarks can block damage, snipers sneak around, assault's jump in to cut you down. There are tons of cool skirmishes to be found and it's an absolute blast.

However it's also the most bare bones part of the game. While the customisation for space marines is great, the chaos marines lack customisation, every class is attached to a traitor legion and is thus bound to it. You cannot play an iron warrior vanguard for instance and the armor itself is barely customisable, sometimes even not. For some of the more chaos minded players this can be quite a big letdown.

The other issue is that while it is 6v6 I can only make a lobby with three people, not six or four, locking out some of my friends to play with, I get it for PVE, I don't for PVP.

PVP feels like something added later in development and I hope that the devs do expand upon it with some much needed Quality of Life changes.


The game is quite CPU heavy, I have a i9-10850k CPU and a RTX4070 TI SUPER, the game runs like a charm in 90% of the game, but some areas and missions are incredible heavy on the CPU so much I wonder if it's a bit of optimalisation. Some area's that are small tank my frames, while some large open areas I run at a solid 80 FPS on ultra settings.

Besides that though, the game is beautiful to look at and effects, lighting, textures are all incredibly impressive, from the sparks of a broken cable to the blood that flies around.

The sound design is really well done and weapon sounds pack the punch you expect them to, every bolt fired, every enemy screech, every punch thrown is of high quality and this combined with the graphical design makes this a very immersive 40K game.


Despite some personal gripes and an in my opinion a bare bones PVP, this game has been worth the wait, it build upon the foundation of Space Marine 1 and improved it immensely. It offers something for older fans and something for newer fans of 40K and it is an incredible home-coming or introduction to the Space Marine franchise and thus Warhammer 40.000. It's an incredibly brutal, fun third person action game and the gameplay loop is quite addicting.

Sabre shows it understands 40K and this game is an ode to it.

Campaign 10/10
PVE: 9/10
PVP 8/10
Graphics 9/10
Sound 9/10

Overall: 9/10

Posted: September 9
Campaign: one of the best I've played in recent memory - this is the only part I can recommend
PvE: repetitive and loses steam after about 3 runs of each map
PvP: not my jam, no opinion, have not played

Overall the combat and general gameplay is some of the most satisfying I've seen since something like Gears but without all the cover nonsense and the first run of the campaign has some real jaw dropping moments in both visuals and reveals.

However, if you're looking for more than the campaign, this is hard to recommend. Much like Left 4 Dead, Back 4 Blood, World War Z, Darktide, etc, there's just nothing to do in the PvE Operations mode except grind out cosmetics and passives. That might be enough for some, but it lacks any of the systems that make something like Destiny, Warframe, Deep Rock Galactic, Remnant, or the plethora of other rougelikes out there that do so much with mapgen and other secondary systems that make each run feel like a run, not just going through the same motions again. I'm never excited by anything that's gonna drop from a mission, it's just "cross the finish line this many times" for your next passive/cosmetic.

Cosmetics are awesome, classes are fine, progression kinda sucks since you only unlock one row at a time. Not sure I'll be playing long enough to max a single class despite only playing two of them. Passives are... there? They all feel like relatively minor gameplay bonuses that help steer your playstyle, but not one so far has made me excited to unlock or feel it was worth working towards. They feel more like bypasses to some inconvenince rather than some Astartes-level power. I don't think I'd be able to tell an endgame level build from an early game one from gameplay alone.

Would be awesome if in new game + you could play the campaign with your custom marine so 60% of the PvE missions were playable with the PvE classes. I think that's my biggest issue, the best PvE content isn't what you get to replay for progression and what's there to replay gets stale fast. Really hope to see some updates to the operations modes that make them more fun to replay. Modifiers, loot drops that persist after a play session, consumable buffs, unique mission rewards, map variants, mapgen, really anything except playing the same mission over and over with some different combat pacing each time.

If campaigns are your jam, pick it up on sale. If you wanted something more replayable, wait.

Posted: September 9
Victorus aut mortis

This review is coming from a perspective of a 40k fan. I am relatively new though, only 5 years ago did I discover this universe, which is quite recent for a universe thats been around since 1987. Since my intoduction I have several painted armies (a space marine one among them) alongside having played some games and listened to a lot of Warhammer books and lore over the years.

Warhammer 40K : Space Marine 2 is a game that absolutely delivers on the experience it was aiming to create while going above and beyond for some aspects while fumbling tiny things along the way. I am pointing this out because this is getting increasingly unusual in the game industry nowadays. Most games coming out trying to sell you a live service while the game is not finished enough to be able to do so. Meanwhile this dev team seems to have taken their time to release a complete product that gives a solid foundation to making a live service work. 3 separate modes, all with a different focus and gameplay experience. Its quite refreshing, but that does not make the game automatically perfect. Lets talk about all of these modes and my thoughts on them.

Campaign: (no spoilers)

This mode continues the story of Demitrian Titus, the protagonist of the first game, with a fancy new narrative 13 years after the games release. Just like the other modes, you can play this mode cooperatively with 2 of your friends, and does a nice job introducing the mechanics of the game in a fun way. The campaign itself is short but sweet, and intentionally tries not to drag on to long, which is good in my opinion because you can't do much character work with a space marine because they are emotionless supersoldiers. The appeal of the campaign are the missions, and the set pieces within them. The 40k universe is bombastic yet intriguing and mysterious, and watching Titus and his team fight through futuristic gothic cities actively being destroyed by the tyranid invasion one moment and navigating through his chapters space ship with tons of details and lore is really fun and engaging. Its like a rollercoaster ride of the 40k universe where they show a lot of the unique and awesome stuff this universe has to offer. I do think it would have been smart of explain some more concepts, especially the ones directly related to the story's plot. A lot of times characters talk about in universe concepts, and people who are new to 40K will just not understand because its never explained. Its tottally playable and comprehensible to a person new going in, but I think its important to explain more stuff to really get them excited about the nuance 40k has compared to other sci-fi universes.

PVE Operations:
This mode allows your to play several missions losely related to the campaign story. Instead of Titus and his squad, you'll be able to play as 6 different classes, and make your own Space Marine. You'll be able to fully customize the look of your character, while completing missions allows you to level up and access new perks and abilities to make your guy stronger over time and really pick a playstyle you like. For 40k fans this is a dream come true since building and painting miniatures is a huge part of this hobby and the amount of customization is pretty vast for game that has just released. Its also not tied to microtransactions and all of the customization (except for a couple skins related to the gold and ultra edition) are earnable through playing the game. No ingame cash shop or lootboxes. The gamemode focusses on replayability with a good variety of maps, enemies and classes alongside the 4, soon to be 5 difficulties, makes it enjoyable over a long period of time. There is also an AI director tha mixes the missions up and tries to suprise you with changes in the enemies that show up and the objectives you must complete along the way. I have some issues with balancing though. The hardest difficulty feels very unstable to play right now, it feels you need to get lucky in order to win, but itâ€™s very satisfying once you do. I also think the Thousand Sons faction are not very fun to fight currently of the way the units are balanced, totally fixable though. Focus has already promised to add more missions, weapons and enemies in the future which will be important to its life service, which in my opinion has the most potential in this game mode.

PVP Eternal War:

I played the least amount of PVP up until now, but it has pleasantly surprised me. Itâ€™s structured as a 6vs6 contest where Space Marines go up against Chaos Space Marines, marines who have betrayed the imperium and have sided with the bad guys. There are a couple modes to pick from, and they are all good fun to play with the same 6 classes from PVE. There only 3 maps though, and unlike the Campaign and PVE, there is not a lot of spectacle going on around or inside of them. Instead, this mode is focused on giving you a more competitive experiences, the 6 classes are all rebalanced to facilitate skill expression and game knowledge. The more you play, the more stuff you unlock for your class and once you get the hang of its surprisingly fun and way more intricate than you thought at first. Donâ€™t overlook it, it might be really your thing.

Conclusion:

To me a perfect game is one that gets a lot of little things right, but at the same time, its art, and how it makes you feel is more important than examining and criticizing every detail. Space Marine 2 gives you the power fantasy of you being among the ranks of the Adeptus Astartes, something every Warhammer nerd fantasizes about ever since they started painting miniatures or reading/listening to the lore of this amazing universe. You get to go along this personal story of Titus to see something curated and then make your own based on the space marine you decide to make for PVE and PVP. The core gameplay is rock-solid and satisfying, with a lot of inspiration taken from DOOM while keeping its own style from the previous game. Artistically and graphically the game looks exactly like fans would envision the 40K universe alongside the overall sound design being a straight 10. The performance overall is impressive considering how many enemies can appear on screen on top of the orchestra of chaos thatâ€™s happening around you.

This by far is the best 40k game Iâ€™ve played so far and deserves all the praise and occasional criticism its receiving. I think thats because people, particularly 40k fans, care about this game and its future; the developers have created an awesome foundation for years of live service support and seem committed to fixing issues through their transparent feedback system. The game has already succeeded critically and financially, now itâ€™s up to the devs build on it. If they do, and they are going to from the looks of their roadmap and their history as a developer, Iâ€™ll be there playing who knows how many years from now. If they somehow donâ€™t, this game is still an incredible game and is easily worth the 60 you put in.

I recommend it, play it if your PC can run it. Thanks for reading this needlessly long steam review, but at the same time, what is wrong with you? You have wasted approximately 5 minutes not serving the emperor.... The inquisition is heading towards your exact location right now.

FOR THE EMPEROR!

Posted: September 9
Visually stunning, musically mediocre, audio in general is the worst part of the game.

Every single gameplay aspect has something holding it back:

- Melee (not enough stagger/damage on higher difficulties especially annoying with the hammer),
- Shooting (barely any gun feels powerful and most of them sound weak too, it's just a feeling though damage is ok)

- Executions/Finishers and other animations where you cant control your character do not have enough invulnerability frames so you take lots of damage without any means to avoid it.

In the end it doesn't matter cause you still feel like a Space Marine and some of the missions are breathtakingly beautiful, just not the second coming of Christ that most of people are telling me this game is.

edit:
- 8/10 if you co op this with a friend or two.
- In this review i'm talking only about the campaign, there are co-op, pvp modes i didnt play enough to have an opinion on them.

Posted: September 9
Many people and I emphasize this many people in these reviews clearly know nothing of what warhammer 40k is and it shows. This game is incredible for long time fans of the franchise and the combat is well developed with the alerts being more of a be aware as opposed to a perfect parry for larger enemies. if you ask me this is a 10/10 for any long time 40k fans. I am excited to see what saber adds. The people who cant play or launch probably dont have the specs for some considering my friends are able to play on a steam deck. For those who need it THIS IS NOT LIKE HELLDIVERS and others its an actually skill issue, learn the mechanics. Your input times matter deeply its based off the animations not just a ding and push. Listen to some lore videos before you jump in making comments its a very long and deep franchise.

Edit after a month. Opinions unchanged still recommend heavily. Sabre interactive listened to people and Everyday I'm counting down to the next content update.

Posted: September 9
En el momento de realizar esta reseÃ±a llevo acumuladas 13 horas de juego, principalmente en el modo CampaÃ±a y algo del modo Operaciones, y el juego, aunque tiene algunos apartados a mejorar, roza el sobresaliente.

Mi experiencia se basa sobre todo en el modo de dificultad Veterano y jugando con amigos en cooperativo, ya que pienso que esta es la autÃ©ntica y mejor experiencia que el juego ofrece. Superar al extremo una situaciÃ³n que parecÃ­a imposible y que todo tu equipo sienta la euforia de la victoria es una gran experiencia.

El juego es un portento a nivel visual, y al menos para equipos modernos estÃ¡ bien optimizado, permitiendo jugar en modo Calidad con bastante fluidez a la que tengas un equipo decente. La ambientaciÃ³n, el mundo de Warhammer 40K, los seres que lo habitan y la escala de sus conflictos estÃ¡n perfectamente recreados. Es increÃ­ble la cantidad de cosas que llegan a suceder en pantalla sin que el rendimiento se resienta.

Aunque el transcurso del juego sea lineal, los escenarios son bastante amplios, ricos en detalles y tienen bastantes recovecos donde se esconden alijos de armamento, recursos o secretos. Dicho esto, en este caso la linealidad, lejos de ser algo negativo, le sienta perfectamente al juego, ya que la intensidad y la tensiÃ³n del conflicto se perderÃ­an con un mundo mÃ¡s abierto. Tal vez sÃ­ estarÃ­a bien contar con mayor exploraciÃ³n y opciones en la Barcaza, pero es algo que ya estÃ¡ planeado para futuras temporadas.

La personalizaciÃ³n de los personajes de los modos multijugador estÃ¡ bastante bien, aunque echo en falta mÃ¡s variedad de piezas, y sobre todo poder cambiar el rostro del personaje (Â¡Quiero a mi lobo espacial barbudo y pelirojo!), pero confÃ­o en que estas opciones que faltan lleguen con expansiones de contenido.

A nivel jugable ofrece un sistema de combate bastante mÃ¡s profundo de lo que cabrÃ­a esperar en un principio, ya que cuenta con un sistema de combos en el que puedes detonar un ataque potente en cualquier momento, de forma que cuanto mÃ¡s esperes para hacerlo mayor serÃ¡ el riesgo, pero tambiÃ©n el daÃ±o causado a los enemigos. Por ejemplo, si lo detonamos en el primer ataque, daremos una patada, en el segundo un empujÃ³n y en tercero un pisotÃ³n que lanzarÃ¡ a los enemigos por los aires y los aturdirÃ¡.

TambiÃ©n cuenta con un sistema de bloqueos (parry) y esquivas, que bien utilizados nos permitirÃ¡n tambiÃ©n aturdir a los enemigos y acabar con ellos rÃ¡pidamente, para regenerar nuestros escudos, aumentando nuestra capacidad de supervivencia.

En cuanto a las armas a distancia, la sensaciÃ³n a los mandos es buena, aunque bastante similar a lo que ya hemos visto en muchos otros juegos de acciÃ³n. Eso sÃ­, tanto en combate a melee como a distancia, el juego ofrece una enorme variedad de armas, asÃ­ que tendremos que decidir cuÃ¡l utilizar en cada situaciÃ³n o cuÃ¡l se adapta mejor a nuestro estilo de juego.

Por Ãºltimo, en combate cada personaje o clase tiene una habilidad especial Ãºnica que se tiene que cargar antes de ser utilizada, pero que nos permite en muchas ocasiones darle la vuelta a una situaciÃ³n desfavorable.

En nivel Veterano, el juego dista mucho de ser un mata-mata, siendo necesario analizar el entorno, identificar las mejores zonas donde buscar cobertura, o dÃ³nde emboscar a los enemigos, asÃ­ como trazar un plan entre todos los jugadores para optimizar sus esfuerzos.

Como puntos negativos, destacarÃ­a algunos errores puntuales que hacen que nuestro personaje atraviese elementos que no deberÃ­a, algÃºn enemigo que se queda atrapado con algÃºn elemento del escenario, unas animaciones faciales que podrÃ­an ser algo mÃ¡s expresivas y las desconexiones del servidor, que aunque no son algo frecuente, cuando ocurren son bastante molestas. TambiÃ©n hubiese estado bien contar con algo mÃ¡s de variedad de situaciones, ya que a pesar de que cuenta con algunos momentos especiales, otros tantos se repiten demasiado. Y por Ãºltimo, algÃºn menÃº puede llegar a ser confuso al principio.

En resumen, a falta de probar el PVP, y que algunos de los errores comentados se vaya corrigiendo, me parece un juego que todo seguidor del gÃ©nero de acciÃ³n o del mundo de Warhammer 40K deberÃ­a probar, sobre todo en su modo cooperativo, tanto en CampaÃ±a como en Operaciones, ya que es un juego bastante bueno y lo serÃ¡ aÃºn mÃ¡s con las expansiones que estÃ¡n por venir.

Posted: September 9
I am struggling to find anything to complain about. My biggest gripe with this game is that I want more, and I think this is a good problem to have.

Encoutered a few annoyances:
- menuing not being too convinient (mostly, I dislike that it takes two screens to set the difficulty+mission combo in the coop mode - it really really REALLY should be one screen). I'd love to see this polished up.
- the game will queue you into lobbies where someone is already playing your class, forcing you to change your class. I feel like that's a bit meh, since I enjoy playing one class for long sessions.
- very rarely (happened about three times in the 18 hours I've played so far) the game will lock you in place for a few seconds after a finisher animation - you're invincible and it'll recover, but it ruins the momentum, allowing the enemies to move away, which is a slight problem for any melee class.

And that's about it. Everything else is awesome. This feels exactly how I'd imagine a supersoldier smashing through the battlefield. The combat system has this heaviness to it, and your hits matter. I haven't felt this much power in my hands since DOOM - and I'm glad to have a new game in my GOAT steam folder.

Good combat (probably one of the best of the genre)

One of the best art direction as today.

Posted: September 8
The long awaited sequel lives up to the hype.
As a 40K fan from the books to the games, I am overly pleased and blown away at the game's detail, gameplay and scope.

The gameplay is clearly a step-up from the simplicity of the first game, adding in just the right amount of abilities, combat mechanics and weaponry.

The campaign's story is hype and larger in scope compared to the first game.

The PvE missions which are closely tied to the campaign are impressive and fun (adds to replayability). At some points I was reminded of Destiny's raids in terms of scale and puzzles (just slimmed down). I am very excited to hear that more of these PvE ops will be added for free in the future. Eternal War PvP is short and sweet, along with what feels like a good balance of classes and perks.

The game's linear progression in the campaign and short single-player reminds me of games from a decade ago, matching the first game's length. If you really enjoyed the first one, this is your new best friend.

Technical issues like crashing in loading screens, crashing after mission completes, server drops, and other small bugs are occasional but not extreme.

As a 40K fan, this will be a game I will come back to for a long time. Even non-40K fans will enjoy this 3rd person action shooter.

Posted: September 8
let me preface this review, it is amazing fun, its beautiful on PC with smooth controls, its campaign is fantastic, a decent amount of customisation rounds it all out, I can see myself able to play this game for many hours.

However, there are some issues, some normal for any games launch as disappointing as they are, some decisions that are just outright stupid until these are fixed even though I love it I cant recommend it.

first and foremost, offline progress is not counted towards your account in operations, now some people have said its an anti cheating measure and I can see that perspective however it pails in comparison to the complete struggle that is trying to play the game in online, as you can expect, like many games of this era online play is wrought with server issues, disconnects mid session, finding it near impossible to get a game going, lag-spikes and jittering all the common symptoms, what this equates too is a game that forces you to play online to progress your account, while being barely able to support online play at all.

this carry's on, if you get disconnected mid session which is very common, you lose all progress, all rewards collected in the mission, you cannot rejoin the game in a standard manner, you cannot carry on the mission with bots in offline mode (even if you could no rewards are likely still an issue.) you get the pure pleasure of being told to go stuff yourself and restart from scratch, one only has so many hours in a day, don't make us waste them.

it is mind blowing to me how one can create a game as beautiful and fun as this and then completely drop the ball at what is completely bloody obvious, the game at launch WILL have server issues, so here's a crack brained idea, maybe don't punish all of your players for the possible action of 1% of players that will cheat in offline mode, in a PVE mission mode if that even was the reasoning behind this decision, its truly mind boggling, Total Biscuit would call it a piece of art with a dumb-ass poking holes in it with a pitchfork, Saber are actively harming players with weak or intermittent internet signals, which makes up a far greater majority, even when the server issues are fixed, which I am sure they are working on.

There are game breaking bugs as well, if you die in some campaign missions on harder difficulties, the ammo boxes disappear, with no spoilers, this makes the mission impossible to progress, not because you cant just chain sword them, but there are enemies and objects you have to shoot, with no ammo to do so.

until bug fixes are done, offline mode grants progression, the servers are fixed, and some truly baffling decisions are reassessed I strongly recommend waiting for the game to go on sale which by then it will hopefully be fixed, or borrow the game and enjoy the best parts about it offline.

you have every part of a great meal here Saber, stop messing it up, you are proactively harming players.

Posted: September 8
Whats my brief summary of Warhammer 40K: Space Marines 2?
Uh...well...
There's Space marines
Loading screens
And buggy cutscenes...

Oh and chainswords....
Mother
F*cking
C H A I N S W O R D S !

In all seriousness yeah its an alright enough game with a short but decent campaign (albeit some aforementioned cutscene errors or bugs such as where they either freeze but the audio continues or its the opposite of the audio lagging behind the visuals of a cutscene).

Combats fun allowing you to pull off some cool as finishers to enemies to regain health and shields (finishing moves in action games is always a win) but some of the controls can feel quite janky with awkward keybinds set by the game for pc.

The operations co-op mode currently has an error where you can get stuck in the hub after readying up for a level and would certainly benefit from some variety, otherwise the same 6 levels could get repetitive for some people, I like to think of it like its Left 4 Dead where you can play through the same levels countless times but the game play is what keeps it fun, but some more random/less linear objectives if possible could probably help make the levels feel less repetitive.
With hopefully some more content and additions operations mode can hopefully reach just a bit more of the potential that it does offer, but still simply just co-op romping with some friends or random allies and curb stomping aliens together are fun solid foundations, hopefully it can just be improved upon.

There's a PVP multiplayer mode where you play as the space marines faction or the Chaos marine (evil hellish marines) faction and fight each other. I haven't played much of it myself but yeah its alright, its there for those who want it.
You can't unfortunately customise the Chaos faction characters, you get premade models for each of the classes on that side, which while they do look cool themselves, does seam like some people are still let down that you can't customise them as well like you can with the space marines.
As far as I've seen theres not many like cool takedowns or anything you can do to enemy players, its just clunky space marines on both sides blasting or thwacking each other clumsily like its a call of duty game and using their ultimate abilities non-stop with no cohesion to see who dies first, then respawning with your abilities charged again to rush back into the fight and repeat the process. Yeah its alright for those who may like the PVP stuff but personally I think the PVE stuff's more the games strong point.

Both the Co-op mode and PVP mode have separate level progressions though so don't think you can level up a class in co-op mode then pop into PVP with a skilled up PVE dude and stomp fools, which is fair BUT however, while class level progression is separate for each mode. You can still unlock cosmetics currency and armour pieces for your characters just by completing matches in both modes as each character. So you can still play both modes and they still count for cosmetic progress at least for each class you beat a match as, so thats nice.

Yeah look, TLDR: Its a decent co-op game and being able to run around and stomp out enemies with allies while playing as giant f*ck off power armoured boys is still awesome. Heck I'm not a big Warhammer series fan myself meaning I knew bugger all about the lore, but I am starting to learn some things about the universe by playing this game and its encouraged me to look a bit more into it.

And you don't need to be a fan of the franchise or know everything to enjoy the game, I'm a simple fella, I saw big mech suits, chainsaws and brutally ripping alien scum to shreads... and thats all I wanted from it.

So its still a solid cool game to play and have fun wreaking havoc on enemies with your big space marine ruthlessness and brutality. But I think it would benefit from some more additions and content, the foundation is there, just build on it and add more levels, and maybe some variety in objectives to keep the co-op mode from becoming stale.

P.S The Season Pass content cosmetics have been a bit disappointing so far, Its just more colours and decals really, I was hoping for more unique/cool and actual standout armour pieces or such to justify its content but so far it leaves alot to be desired IMO.

Posted: September 8
This game has the feel and vibe of a game made in the late 2000s, early 2010s. The way the multiplayer and the PvE modes play wouldn't be out of place in that era, minus the graphics. This isn't as common nowadays, if at all. So in a weird way, it's a refreshing change that I don't hate at all.

The game currently lacks any microtransactions, and apparently there's no concrete plans for modern microtransaction models. You want new cosmetics? Play the game modes. You want new weapons? Play the game modes. This is good. I like this.

The gameplay feels similar to how the first Space Marine did, with significant improvements in some areas, and a few missteps. The biggest issue comes in the form of the difficulty, as some enemies are just obnoxiously too powerful on their own, with the methods that they swarm you making it all the worse to deal with. This really only is an issue I've found with the Tyranids. The moment you get to your second set of enemies, it's nowhere near as bad.

Also what is the point of a heavy bolter if a simple SHIELD can stop it?

Edit: After patches and ultrawide support this game is what it was supposed to be at launch

Posted: September 8
Story is about 10 hours of gameplay (including doing the side coop missions at least once, that are part of the story, but also the content you grind after) and I enjoyed it for what it was. I think this is a great intro to the 40k universe/lore for people new to it.

The gameplay is fun and with the classes and guns available right now there is enough variation to enjoy and keep playing. Where the game does lack though, is the mission content. The re-playable/grind-able missions I feel will get a bit boring after maybe 20-30 hours of grinding them. There is some variation in spawns (elites/bosses can spawn in certain parts of the mission path) but with the few missions that you can run, it isn't enough. Granted the devs plan to expand this later.

There is a PVP mode that will extend the games life a bit but I am yet to try it, although I think it is probably gonna be quite fun.

The game looks beautiful and runs smooth for me (7950x3d, 4090FE, 64gb 6000mhz ram) with the only issue being - when I try to quit the game, it doesn't actually quit. I have to kill it manually.

Overall, id recommend this but if you are only here for the story - wait for it to be expanded with DLC releases or wait for the game to go on a 50% sale. I also got the ultra edition - don't do this unless you just want to support the game, the content it gives you over the Gold isn't really worth it.

Posted: September 8
Fantastic. Itâ€™s exactly what you'd expect from a sequel to 2011â€™s Space Marine and a Warhammer 40K action game. It takes everything that made the first game fun and cranks it up, refining pretty much everything that you remember about that original game.

I never followed the details about the story prior to the release so I wasn't sure if it's gonna pick up from where the last game left off. But I was pleased to see that not only does it still feature Captain Titus as the main character, but also manages to be an overall much better story with a couple of fun memberberries thrown in for fans of the original.

And if you're really invested in the lore, you'll be pleased to know that the developers poured a lot of heart and attention into making this an accurate 40K experience. It's probably the most authentic "play as a Space Marine" experience to date, because you truly feel like an eight-foot-tall truck on legs, towering over regular humans and barreling through everything like an elephant in a china shop. Including any living thing that isn't at least as big, because it's going to end up getting stomped like a grape. Everything about this game's design is just as over-the-top, excessive, and ludicrous as you'd expect, and it's glorious.

THE EMPEROR PROTECTS!

Posted: September 8
This is in my honest opinion the best Warhammer 40k game we've ever had. It does a lot of things very well, and very little outright bad.

The story is good but nothing mind-bending. There's the usual 40k war drama. A few nice twists, and some truly breath catching moments. All of that is if you're a fan of the setting.

If you're not, or yet undecided, then this is a very good entry point. The game does an amazing job showing the scale of conflicts that take place in the universe. Then it impresses you with its visuals and sound design and does not stop.


Things of note, multiplayer (both PVE and PVP) have customization, and the story clocked for me at around 12 hours at the hardest difficulty. Performance seems good enough, though people mention crashing and CPUs going very hot, so keep that in mind.

And well, that's it. It's a great game. It looks great, it plays great, and it sounds great.

Posted: September 7
Space Marine 2 is easily one of the top games in the Warhammer 40K universe. After 13 long years of waiting since the excellent first game, it was absolutely worth the anticipation. To be completely honest, I got my hands on it early thanks to the leak in July, but since I knew Iâ€™d be buying the full version (and went all out for the maximum edition), I think that excuses my impatience. I simply couldn't wait!

Campaign

The sequelâ€™s story picks up directly from the first game, even though about 200 years have passed in the timeline. The campaign is as grand as youâ€™d hope, fitting perfectly within the Warhammer 40K universe. Blood, gruesome executions, and limb-tearing battles define this world, and the game delivers on all fronts. While itâ€™s linear and heavily focused on combat, I found the whole experience a ton of fun.

Combat Mechanics

The combat truly nails the feeling of being an unstoppable, armored giant. From the moment you start the campaign itâ€™s clear that you are super-human. The Ultramarines stand out from the surroundings and look like some sort of Titans, with their sheer size making them equals to the Tyranid warriors. The weight and power of your weapons â€?both melee and ranged â€?feel spot on, especially when playing with a controller (Iâ€™m using an Xbox one). Each hit, shot, and headshot feels impactful, and those bloody finishing moves? Just perfect.

Co-op Mode

A great addition is the new co-op mode. After the introductory mission, you can jump into the campaign with one or two friends, and it works flawlessly. It really amps up the excitement of playing together. If you're playing solo, the AI companions are excellent, so you wonâ€™t feel left out.

Multiplayer

And now for the real treat: multiplayer. If you have fond memories of the multiplayer from the original Space Marine, youâ€™re in for a treat. It was brilliant back then and kept me entertained for hours. Now, after 13 years, we finally have what weâ€™ve been waiting for. The multiplayer alone makes Space Marine 2 worth buying. If you're into the Warhammer 40K universe, thereâ€™s no better PvP experience out there.

In my opinion, itâ€™s a solid 10/10. Definitely worth checking out!

After playing the PvE / PVP and finishing the campaign I must say this game feels like a blast from the past.
Throughout the story I felt like I was a teenager again, its weird to explain. I felt like I did back when the original gears of war or halo games came out, nostalgic almost. Haven't had a game give me that feeling in a long time.
You can tell the devs put some love into this game, it shows.

What an absolute joy it is to slaughter xenos filth in the name of The Emperor while repping the Salamander Green.

Does seem a bit performance heavy, so maybe some optimizations will be on their way soon enough. No real impact on my experience as I'm running a bit of an overpriced rig however because of that I always run a frame rate counter and monitor temps out of obsession.

Highly recommending this to anyone that loves the Space Marines foremost, and Warhammer 40ks beautiful cast of characters.

Posted: September 7
Speaking as a person who has invested far more money into tabletop warhammer than I care to consider, who has read dozens of black library books this game is the best representation of 40k I've ever seen outside of writing. There is so much love and attention to detail in this game that it could truly have only been made by people who are enormous fans of the setting. I don't want to spoil things before the game is even fully out but let me say the scene with the chapter banner was AMAZING and it might not have even been the coolest moment in the game. I constantly felt like I was seeing the stories and miniatures I know so well brought to life, it was a really remarkable thing.

The performance is also like, weirdly good? I only have a 3700x // RX 7800XT and it ran flawlessly all the way through the campaign at 1440P, on Linux no less. It's pretty remarkable. Really feels like the time they spent during the delay was very well spent indeed.

If you care about warhammer 40k literally at all I cannot recommend this game strongly enough. Even if you don't I'd say it stands quite well on its own merit as well

Posted: September 7
I just built a new computer 2 weeks ago.
Ryzen 7 7800X3D
GeForce RTX 4080 Super
64GB DDR5 RAM

The game has crashed 3 times so far, each time causing my entire computer to crash. I've adjusted the settings each time in hopes of avoiding another crash.

One friend had his GPU suddenly start failing/showing artifacts. Another friend has high temp CPU. This is the 'only' game this has happened on.

Oh, and scrubbing the "play PvP with up to 5 friends in 6v6 matches" and capping a party to 3 people is a very low blow.

Definitely needs some fixing as far as performance goes. Until then, thumbs down.

Posted: September 7
Having a blast, main game campaign whoever was responsible with the lore part got it pretty well and the last boss was really fun with my friends in the Angels of Death difficulty. Now I'm playing Ops with them and let me tell you, its another campaign with its own story. Stuff that happen while Titus takes care of the main course so to say. I really recommend checking it.

My only minor complaint, PvP chaos marines not being able to customize their stuff. And Salamanders when you pick their customization the Adeptus Astartes not getting obsidian skin and red eyes. Devs please include it when you pick the Salamanders chapter I presume it shouldn't be hard to implement such thing.

Performance wise it was all right for me I think I just presence 5-6 stutters during my whole gameplay in the campaign and it seems its something related with the green effect from the Tyranids that cause it but I can't pinpoint if is the spores or the psychic effect , my current specs:

Amd Ryzen 7 5800X3D
16 GB RAM
3080 RTX TI
Installed the game on SSD
W10 OS

Posted: September 7
Roleplaying game, gameplay very average, dont buy now, wait for a year at least.

Very bad servers, EXTREMELY long loading screens, PVP has 3 Maps with the most shallow design possible, no Ranked System or leader board or any Private lobbies, cant choose server location, constant disconnection. Some load out systems legit have 2 options only for PVP, and the second option is locked behind 20+ hours of grind. MUST MUTE ANNOUNCER IN PVP, the voice lines loop every time someone goes on the objectives.

Ai teammates are completely useless if you play solo, combat system tries to replicate Vermintide and Darktide but fails, The grey health restoration mechanic is minimal and the shields are obsolete as they get deleted in 1 hit. Higher difficulties are unbalanced because of the power scaling of your character, the upgrades are disappointing and lackluster, 5% melee dmg when mobs HP doubles does â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™? No attachments for your gear, Perks have no choices, just linear upgrades with some special nodes.

PVE Operative mode is good tho if you have people to play with, Quick match is too slow and drops you into dead matches.

Posted: September 7
The Emperor protects. Running the game on 1660Ti. While keeping it on Low I am getting very solid frame rate. Loving it. The controls might be a bit odd until you get used to it but overall a great game.

Not a single crash so far or game breaking bugs.

Posted: September 6
shut the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up about wider screen resolution, u are a small group compared to the larger pie, this game is easily game of the year just going off on the campaign alone. the co-op crossplay is stable and as of writing this i have yet to play the eternal war mode but i am very excited to do so after having beaten the campaign. i myself had a rocky start launching this game, many attempts at tinkering with options to get past the first intro cutscene but i came in to this game with tempered expectations, and after overcoming this small obstacle, discovered the true glory this game has to offer.

my only critique is that the loading screens can sometimes detract from the immersive gameplay, and often times at least in my case take a fair bit of time. other than that this game is the peak that mankind has been reaching for since the OG space marine

Ihre Horden wogen wie eine lebendige Flut Ã¼ber die Stellungen der Verteidiger hinweg, und das Spiel fÃ¤ngt die schiere Masse und Grausamkeit dieser Kreaturen meisterhaft ein.

Die Geschichte selbst entfaltet sich als epischer Kampf um das Ãœberleben der Menschheit. Captain Titus, geschmiedet im Feuer zahlloser Schlachten, muss nicht nur gegen Ã¤uÃŸere Feinde kÃ¤mpfen, sondern auch gegen innere Zweifel. Die Frage, was es wirklich bedeutet, ein Space Marine zu sein â€?eine unaufhaltsame TÃ¶tungsmaschine oder der letzte Verteidiger der Menschheit â€? wird immer wieder aufgegriffen. Doch wer Captain Titus kennt, weiÃŸ, dass seine Treue unerschÃ¼tterlich bleibt, und dies macht ihn zu einem wahrhaft legendÃ¤ren Charakter.


- Gameplay â€?Der Donner des Bolters und das Heulen der Kettenschwerter

Das Gameplay von Space Marine 2 ist wie ein donnernder Hymnus an den Krieg. Das Spiel fÃ¤ngt die Essenz eines Space Marines perfekt ein: Du bist kein gewÃ¶hnlicher Soldat â€?du bist ein wandelnder Panzer, eine lebendige Waffe des Imperators, gemacht um Tausende von Feinden zu vernichten. Das GefÃ¼hl der Macht, wenn man den Abzug eines Bolters drÃ¼ckt und sieht, wie Feinde in Blut und Fleisch explodieren, ist unÃ¼bertroffen.

Das Nahkampfsystem ist eine brutale Symphonie aus Klingen und FÃ¤usten. Die Kettenschwerter brÃ¼llen und sÃ¤gen sich durch die Reihen der Feinde, wÃ¤hrend die SchlÃ¤ge eines Energiehammers Wellen der ZerstÃ¶rung durch ganze Formationen senden. Jeder Treffer, jeder Schlag fÃ¼hlt sich mÃ¤chtig an, und die audiovisuelle Umsetzung unterstreicht dies perfekt â€?von den metallischen KlÃ¤ngen der ServorÃ¼stung bis hin zu den knirschenden Knochen und reiÃŸenden Sehnen der Feinde.

Neu hinzugefÃ¼gt wurde eine verfeinerte Mechanik fÃ¼r AusweichmanÃ¶ver und taktisches Vorankommen. Dies verleiht den KÃ¤mpfen eine zusÃ¤tzliche strategische Ebene, ohne den Fluss des BlutvergieÃŸens zu unterbrechen. Besonders beeindruckend ist die Art, wie das Spiel die Zahl der Gegner handhabt â€?riesige SchwÃ¤rme von Tyraniden, die auf dich zustÃ¼rmen, und du allein, ein wandelnder Gott des Krieges, der sie niedermetzelt. Es ist eine brutale, kathartische Erfahrung, die jeden Warhammer-Fan begeistern wird.


- Grafik und Sound â€?Ein audiovisuelles Meisterwerk

Die Welt von Warhammer 40k wird in Space Marine 2 mit unglaublicher Detailtreue zum Leben erweckt. Die zerklÃ¼fteten Schlachtfelder, die gottlosen Alienarchitekturen und die prÃ¤chtigen RÃ¼stungen der Space Marines â€?all dies erstrahlt in glorreicher, blutiger Pracht. Besonders hervorzuheben ist die Gestaltung der Tyraniden. Jedes Glied, jede Kralle und jeder zahnbewehrte Schlund dieser abscheulichen Kreaturen wurde mit Liebe zum Detail geschaffen und wirkt wahrhaft furchteinflÃ¶ÃŸend.

Der Soundtrack begleitet die KÃ¤mpfe mit dÃ¼steren, epischen KlÃ¤ngen, die dem Spieler das GefÃ¼hl geben, Teil eines gewaltigen Kreuzzugs zu sein. Die GerÃ¤usche des Schlachtfelds â€?das Rattern der Bolter, das metallische BrÃ¼llen der RÃ¼stungen und das markerschÃ¼tternde Heulen der Tyraniden â€?sind so intensiv, dass man fast den SchweiÃŸ und das Blut riechen kann.


- Fazit â€?Im Namen des Imperators, es gibt keinen Vergleich

Space Marine 2 ist nicht nur ein Spiel, sondern eine Erfahrung. Es fÃ¤ngt die Essenz dessen ein, was es bedeutet, ein Space Marine zu sein: ein Krieger, der in einem Universum voller Tod und Chaos kÃ¤mpft und niemals zurÃ¼ckweicht. Die Mischung aus intensiven, brutalen KÃ¤mpfen, der dÃ¼steren, tiefgrÃ¼ndigen Geschichte und der atemberaubenden audiovisuellen PrÃ¤sentation macht es zu einem Muss fÃ¼r jeden Fan des Warhammer 40k-Universums â€?und fÃ¼r jeden, der den Imperator ehren will.

Dieses Spiel ist ein Monument des Krieges, errichtet auf dem Blut und den Knochen der Feinde des Imperators.

FÃ¼r den Imperator! FÃ¼r das Imperium! Kein Bedauern, kein RÃ¼ckzug, nur Sieg!

column5: en

Posted: September 6
Rise, Son of Guilliman

After finishing the campaign I just had to write a review to get my thoughts down on paper, this review will contain no spoilers for the story, but will talk about themes, gameplay and performance. Together of course with an overall impression, to start things off.

Space Marine 2 exceeded my expectations by a significant margin, this game is fun to play. I've seen some other reviews talking about how the combat system is "unforgiving", but I can only say that I disagree. The fast paces melee / ranged blend is really satisfying once you figure out what works for you. I played the game on the second to highest difficulty for my first run so far, I had to adjust in the beginning but once I got over the hurdle, quite frankly I just saw myself improving and getting better at managing the fights. To an extent fights in this game feel reminiscent of those from DOOM, specifically Eternal. Every fight is a puzzle that you need to think creatively to solve together with staying on top of incoming attacks and positioning.

Complaints about the AI are valid, but I didn't notice much in terms of them getting in the way of me having fun.

Performance wise, I'm running on a fairly old rig, 1080 and an i7-4790k, and I got stable performance albeit not exceptional on the high preset. For me I am fine if a game runs at 30 as long as it is stable, and Space Marine 2 was, depending on level, either running at stable 30, stable 45, stable 60 or unstable 20-30. The 20-30 range being in some of the later where the game is flexing it's muscle in terms of scale and the number of effects on screen.

As for all the stuff with the Epic integration? Quite literally you accept the EULA and that's it. It has no other impact on your gameplay. I find complaints around this sort of stuff to be valid, if exaggerated. It is okay to be upset that this is "forced" upon you, but I do not think it warrants leaving a negative review for the game, personally.

Story? This feels like it could've been a 40k novel. I say that with significant praise, compared to the first game the stakes are higher, the characters are better, and it just feels like a part of actual canon now.

I am incredibly satisfied, and depending on how the game develops in the next few years, it might take the spot for "My personal favorite 40k game", as it is now, however? Firmly top 3.

Suffice to say, I strongly recommend this game, I will be diving into the multiplayer and co-op components in the next few days, and if there is anything to add or detract from this review, expect addenda :)

If no addenda are found on this review, my stance holds firm.

Posted: September 6
Product received for free

With Space Marine II, Saber interactive proves, once again, that they know how to do action games, this time adding a ton of Co-op & PvP options powered by their squeaky-clean net code. The game runs excellently, looking great and performing to specification. I was able to stream it from the same rig I was playing on, and only got one random crash during my five-hour session. Visuals are great, audio is fantastic, and the writing found here is far better than any game in the genre usually gets. The Swarm Engine that made WWZ what it is comes into play and provides a breathtaking sense of scale to most encounters. The price-tag might be a bit steep, at least when we are talking about the Early Access Versions, but they come packed with the first Season Pass, which will eventually make the investment worth it. If you are looking for a really well-crafted action games to play with your friends, will not disappoint. To War!



- FiOth

Into the fires of battle, unto the anvil of war

Posted: September 6
I paid $90 bucks for this?...

You bet your sweet ass I did. I cannot express what an amazing experience this was as a 40K fan, I haven't touched anything except the story, just finished it in fact, and I was completely blown away. The scale of the set pieces, fan service galore, and all of the Tyranids and Chaos Servants you can ea- um, annihilate, I can feel the love that the devs put into this masterpiece coming inside me.

If you're a fan of 40K, and you liked the original Space Marine game, or you like hack and slash 3PS games, you need to pick this up. This was a labor of love that we may never see again if these f*cking morons leaving negative reviews have their way.

Some sound mixing issues, very few physics based glitches, and absolutely fantastic performance with TWO, COUNT EM TWO hitches in the framerate in my entire playthrough due to I'm guessing shader compilations. This is the most polished game I played in 2024.

Anyone leaving negative reviews for this game because of the Epic stuff? You're a pathetic POS. You will never be able to use Epic Games anything without accepting their TOS, so how the ever living F*CK are you going to sue them? You're apparently not using their products anyways, troglodytes.

Epic already has your data, you're on Steam, just shut up. Parroting worthless BS you don't understand is painful to read, if you had anything worth hiding you wouldn't be leaving a whiny review with less than an hour of game play, you're not helping anyone, and I am coming to your house to sleep with both of your parents while you cry in their basement.

ĞŸĞ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğµ 8,5 Ğ¸Ğ· 10 (Ğ¢Ğ¸Ñ‚ Ğ½Ğµ "Ğ·Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ¸Ñ‚Ñ‹Ğ²Ğ°ĞµÑ‚ Ğ¼Ñ‹ÑĞ»ÑŒ Ğ´Ğ½Ñ" , Ğº Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ½Ğ°Ğ¼Ğ¸ĞºĞµ Ğ±Ğ¾Ñ Ğ½Ğ°Ğ´Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ²Ñ‹ĞºĞ°Ñ‚ÑŒ)
Ğ˜ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑĞ»ĞµĞ´Ğ½ĞµĞµ Ñ Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑˆÑƒ, Ğ½ĞµÑ‚ ÑƒĞ¼Ğ¾Ğ»ÑÑ Ñ‡Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‹ Saber Interactive ÑĞ´ĞµĞ»Ğ°Ğ»Ğ° Ñ€ĞµĞ¼Ğ°ÑÑ‚ĞµÑ€ Ğ¿ĞµÑ€Ğ²Ğ¾Ğ¹ Space Marine!!

Well, this is my first review.
I'll say right away that the game is quite good, no, even excellent. A worthy continuation of the first Space Marine.
And I want to give credit to Relic Entertainment, because this studio "laid the foundation" of the series.
I also want to thank the Saber Interactive studio for a "quality" product. And a pretty good plot (although honestly it is short compared to the first part (purely my opinion)).
The combat system is quite dynamic (even very much, I want a little "old")
The environment is generally the bomb, you feel the "scope and epicness"
I'll give the game 8.5 out of 10 (Titus does not "read out the thought of the day", you need to get used to the dynamics of the battle)
And the last thing I ask, no, I beg that Saber Interactive make a remaster of the first Space Marine!!

column5:
Posted: September 6
The game has immersive and astonishing visuals and gets really the wonder of the Warhammer 40k universe grandeur and epic proportions. This can definitely give some inspiration and feel of ave to anyone really interested in the 40k universe.

The gameplay is quite a copy from Warhammer 40k Darktide, in all aspects of level design, weapon design, visuals. Unfortunately this also mean the gameplay, weapons design and level design and enemies are as they were in Darktide. This game however is not some aspiring storm trooper learning to survive, but this is a game where the player is put into the boots of a Space Marine, as super soldier with genetic and technological superiority, an Emperor's angel that alone can take tides of baddies etc.

The problems are soon too apparent and disturb severely the feel given to the player. Weapons have extreme recoil, they have too low damage and too low range and in many cases even too low ammo capacity. You get the feel of being scared, alone, restricted... Not the feeling of being the best there is going with brave heart towards what might look as if being suicidal odds and still expect to come out as unscratched and victorious. The devs should at least to a minimum add the target enhancing and dark vision to be constant things for the Space Marines, not some random and seldom few second bonuses. Also while at it the recoil should mostly go away as the guys here do have the power armour of the best sort and the usual recoil from heavy weapons is nothing to these guys. More over the also have Auspex inbuilt to their helmets, super senses, dark vision, automatic sensor arrays around them etc. This should give them really good combat awareness at all times and extreme accuracy with any weapons. The weapons are also needing to get some sort of a update... It feels so sad to fire a large caliber bolter at some hormagaunt to only see that it fights on and did not even lose a limb or so, and this happens with EVERY round... It get so annoyingly sad too soon... For some reason they also chose not to copy the sound from Darktide, and bolters, chain swords, power swords etc. all sound so lame (which unfortunaly is also lame in effects too)... These Space Marines should be able to kill things with far more less effort than the game makes you do especially if trying anything but the Easy mode. Also the Space Marine power armour is merely more resilient than the health and life points in Darktide making the player die and suffer in situations that are barely seeming dangerous.

Please devs, make the above fixes to the gameplay and also add much more damage to every marine weapon and especially the Heavy Bolter, Plasma Pistol, Plasma Gun, and Meltagun all need to feel like they are some weapons of mass destruction even against bosses. Just allow us feel like god-like super soldiers and not some decent elite commando guys... Make the armour withstand things much more... Currently the tolerance is just pathetic... And while at it, get rid of the dodge roll animation finally... Just allow the super soldier to take a quick leap of some two meters or so worth... The super quick dodge roll in a 300kg armour just really is like a bad bad thing for the immersion. Movent which btw is otherwise very nicely done to give the character some very heavy feel otherwise with all the noises and thumps and slight slowness. It would also be nice if you devs could get some effects where the enemies lose limbs and weapons while being shot at and losing capability to attack or move along. This way you can still allow the enemies to withstand occasionally some bolt or two extra. MAybe also make the enemies have some weak points where they are wounded heavily with shots instead of just being hp reduction thing for them. Though the melee blocking and execution shots are very nice.

The game has been developed as being another Darktide with different skin and seems like the devs wanted the main game to be the multiplayer deathmatch / team match thing instead of the campaign where you go against tyranids... If wanting to get a feel of being a Space Marine among a tyranid invasion, this is not so much of a giving the feeling, but just baing visually very immersive 40k thingy then,

So, it appears as though the dev has fixed major connection issues for coop.

The game is the best Warhammer game out there. There was so much love and detail poured in. It's just a great action game that's not clunky and is incredibly responsive. I want to type more but you should just look at professional reviewers instead of me.

I hope you love this as much as me. My friends and I, including my wife (who is now a 40k fan) have had limitless fun post connection fix.
